Bio:
Pramod Parajuli, Ph.D.
Founder and Thought Leader, Annapurna Abundance: Learning to Regenerate while Regenerating to Learn
https://www.youtube.com/@annapurnaabundance5693

Founding Core Faculty
Doctoral Program in Visionary Practice and Regenerative Leadership
Southwestern College, Santa Fe, New Mexico
https://www.swc.edu/pramod-parajuli-ph-d-program-faculty/

As a trans-disciplinary social scientist, scholar and educator, Dr. Parajuli is deeply seeking ways to heal and regenerate lifesystems, livelihoods, learning and leadership during this turbulent period (especially since 2020) of what he identifies as the “Combined Climate/Coronaviruses Disruptions” (CCCDs).  He recognizes CCCDs as a valid and unavoidable response of Gaia to give us the mirror to reassess ourselves and our pathways. Where and how the human world has caused the deep erosion into its own pathways? Why and how are our pathways at the detriment of the bio-geo-chemical cycles? Responding to such an urgent situation he is engaged and invites others to deeply explore both the “epochal” and “epical” dimensions of this moment. Clearly impacting from cellular to cosmic, at this juncture, the message is clear: 
HUMANITY is NOT at the center. LIFE, LIFESYSTEMS and WEBS of LIFE which envelop the ecosphere and every species on earth, ARE. 

Professor Parajuli’s engaged pedagogies and scholarship are thus guided by the premise that at this critical juncture, the choices humanity has is between: “Upcycling to Regenerative,” or by default, “Downcycling to Degenerative.” What we do now is entirely upon us. Our ecospheric home (the Gaia) is already doing and will do what she needs to do. Gaia has endured long enough of our excesses and there is no room for us to continue the run-away extraction and plunder of the earthly processes.

 A passionate educator/advisor, professor Parajuli has designed 2 Masters and 2 doctoral programs while successfully graduating 37 doctoral advisees and about 70 Masters students who are pioneering regenerative pedagogies and leadership work throughout the world. A graduate of Stanford in education, anthropology, and political ecology (1983-1990), he has taught at Stanford, Syracuse U (1991-98), Lewis and Clark College (1998-99), International Honors Program (1999-2000), Portland State (2001-2008), Prescott College (2008-2020), and Southwestern College (2020-). He is also active in the networks of Ubiquity University, Ecoversities, and the Regenerative Communities Network (RCN). 

At Portland State (PSU), he designed and developed an interdisciplinary Master’s program, Leadership in Ecology, Culture and Learning and also co-initiated Learning Gardens program. One of his proudest contributions, through the award-winning Learning Gardens initiative, his team actualized the promise of connecting the university with K-12 landscape and the collectivity of children and youth, teachers and their parents. In this award-winning program, children and youth not only learn how to garden but they gardened to learn. A pleasant surprise for all, they gardened to learn every subject, almost grade-by-grade, topic-by-topic, week-by-week, and subject-by-subject. At PSU, he also nurtured another national award-winning innovation on the theme of Schools as Ecosystems. In this online learning platform, children and youth could turn their schools as living-learning laboratories and engage in 36 plus design and regenerative activities. 

In 2008, he moved to the high desert of Colorado Plateau to start a new phase and engage at Prescott College. He embraced and embodied, another ecosystem, another reality. Here he served as the Core faculty for the PhD program in sustainability education and offered leadership in designing and developing new graduate programs. 
A prolific writer and thought leader in pedagogical, social and applied sciences, Dr. Parajuli has coined and contributed the notions of integrative socio-ecological regeneration (ISER), “social movement pedagogy,” “critique of development discourse,” “ecological ethnicities,” “bio-cultural diversities,” “soil-to supper/sustenance pedagogies,” “permaculture household,” “Gandhian environmentalism,” “environmentalism of the global south,” “Annapurna pluriversities” and “regenerative abundance.” Dr. Parajuli has published widely in the intersection of pedagogy, political ecology, food systems, and social sciences.  He is the co-editor of the volume, Religion and Sustainable Agriculture (2016). 
Links to publications and scholarly presentations:
Researchgate: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Pramod_Parajuli 
Academia: https://prescott.academia.edu/PramodParajuli 
Presentations at Humanity Rising Global Solutions Summit, Day 209 (March 22, 2021)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xHXVQYJqm-Q 
Followed by second session on (April 21, 2021) 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=owbbcPB_ut0&t=114s
Name: Pramod Parajuli

Bio:
As Founder and Director of Firmrock Agri-Water Initiative, I am committed to driving sustainable agricultural practices that address the core challenges of hunger, water scarcity, and poverty in Kenya's arid and semi-arid regions. Our mission is to empower local communities by providing innovative farming techniques, water management solutions, and value-added agriculture that promote both economic growth and food security.

We are currently launching a large-scale cassava and sweet potato farming project, beginning with a 5-acre demonstration hub and training 50 local farmers to replicate this model on their ½-acre plots 

 This initiative not only focuses on cultivating drought-resistant crops but also incorporates value addition by processing cassava and sweet potatoes into flour and starch. We take a zero-waste approach, converting by-products like pulp and peels into animal feed to ensure resource efficiency.

 In addition, we are exploring the potential of sweet potato leaves for plant-based protein extraction, an exciting venture that could boost both nutrition and economic opportunities for the community.

 At Firmrock, our focus extends beyond agriculture. We are tackling the root causes of hunger, water shortages, and poverty by building resilient, self-sustaining communities.
 
 We are actively seeking partnerships and resources to scale this initiative and broaden our impact. If you're passionate about sustainable agriculture, innovative solutions, or community empowerment, I’d love to connect and explore how we can collaborate to create lasting change.

Bio:
I am a physical geographer and permaculture designer. I have worked for the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) in Geneva from 2000 to 2021, addressing global environmental issues. Linking global interests and goals with local actions, especially in the form of regenerative agriculture inspired by permaculture, is one of my main concerns. I am co-author of the book "Die Humusrevolution" and initiator of the symposium and webinar series "Ressource building Agriculture". I am living in the ecovillage/community Schloss Tempelhof since the end of 2012, where I also help to shape purely practical methods of regenerative agriculture.

On LinkedIn, see my blog "Climate Landscapes" (https://www.linkedin.com/company/84937202), or http://climate-landscapes.org.

Bio:
I dedicate my career to expanding the social impact of third sector organizations, aligning the different visions of the areas and actors around a common purpose. I structure resources and operations helping to make each institution more efficient and sustainable.

I have worked in strategic positions in some of the main institutions in Brazil, accumulating valuable knowledge along the way.

I have achieved significant results in different contexts, ranging from the multiplication of the volume of resources and teams of the institutions to successful restructuring processes ('turnaround'). I accounted for more than R$ 100 million in numerous audits and projects with highly visible tax incentives, without reservations. The security of my work supports and drives the final goal.
I believe that we generate more value when we combine passion for causes with good management practices. The focus of my work is to promote effective social transformation and contribute to a fairer future.
Name: Fernando Rebello

Bio: Nathan was born and raised in San Diego and has completed an AS in Agriculture from Yuba College, and BS in Natural Resources, with special emphasis in Fish and Wildlife Conservation, from Oregon State University. With more than 15 years of cultivation experience, Nathan has developed a passion for agroforestry, community ecology, and mycorrhizal systems. Nathan is the co-founder and executive director of Mongol Tribe, a community and capacity building 501c3 focused on bridging health and wellness with civic ecology. Mongol Tribe’s pillars focus on co-operative development, regenerative land care practices, and education. Our Food & Medicine Sovereignty Program is cultivating edible arboretums and seed libraries throughout our community. Through our Natural Land Management Program we are developing a forestry school at the 67-acre Nate Harrison Serenity Ranch in Palomar Mountain, CA. We are curating workshops, festivals, internships, and apprenticeships with an emphasis in traditional ecological knowledge (TEK), regenerative agroforestry practices, and holistic health & wellness. Nathan is currently utilizing GIS to perform vegetative surveying for forest health, with special emphasis on oak trees and ethnobotanical species. Nathan has an active practice in natural time, embodying the 13-moon calendar and harmonizing his rhythms with the tides and seasons. His ancestry is composed of Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Mongolian, Sri Lankan, Indian, Peruvian, and Northern European. He invokes Quan Yin, embodies Ryujin, and carries the medicine of bear, whale, and salmon.

Bio:
Co-President, 4Terra.eco 

I am a multi award-winning sustainability innovator, entrepreneur, strategist, coach and advisor. 

In the 1990s, I developed a process for rapid remediation of contaminated soil using fungi and bacteria and cleaned up multiple former gas works facilities, oil refineries and other post-industrial sites across the UK.

In the 2000's I pioneered the use of advanced data-driven visualisations for sustainability strategy and formulated or refined and implemented sustainability strategies for multiple corporations from SMBs to multinationals, the Federal Government of Canada, the State Government of California and around 40 other states, counties and cities.

I have been a speaker, including keynote presentations, at multiple sustainability/CSR/ESG conferences worldwide, including EcoCity events in San Francisco, Istanbul and Vancouver and have appeared on BBC and CBC television.

Bio:
Hello,

I hope you are well!

I work for an organization called Climate Wise, dedicated to offsetting carbon emissions to mitigate the impacts of global warming and climate change. We support meaningful initiatives to mitigate the changes to our planet caused by human activities and their increasingly devastating effects, alongside supporting sustainable development.

We have a podcast at Climate Wise called Net Zero Conversations. I am in the process of planning our next series on nature-based solutions. I was wondering if anyone from your organisation would be willing to join me for an episode to discuss your solution.

Each episode is just a 10-15 informal chat, I can send over questions beforehand too so you know what to expect.

Let me know what you think! Looking forward to hearing from you. :)

Best wishes,
Katrine

Bio: PRIDO is a community-based rural development organization that seeks to support sustainable development initiatives in Sierra Leone. The organization had used a community-based approach promoting the formation of groups to solve environmental issues, food insecurity and build resilience at the household level. The organization with over ten years of community service has grown to the extent that operating as a representative of common people of the rural areas; it seeks to create a future of hope for the marginalized women, youths, children and their communities by helping them to build their skills and resources to reduce their vulnerability in a sustainable way.
Name: Joe Musa

Bio:
About
One of my biggest inspirations in life is the resiliency and generosity found in nature, the possibility to reduce poverty, restore dignity, rebuild soils, and restore food and water security for people, livestock and all life. 

I am a founding trustee and Director of IGugu Trust, African Coordinator for Regeneration International. I am also a trainer, accredited professional (Communal) in Holistic Management by Savory Institute. 
My experience is designing a regenerative organization and programs. I have 18 years of experience in programs curation, curriculum development, community organizing, networking, land monitoring and using Holistic Management process to implement regenerative actions.

My main interest is to promote abundance thinking and reverse poverty, desertification, loss of wildlife, and climate change and its effects. 

I am also a contributor to different networks on the continent; PELUM, Seed and Knowledge Initiative and Alliance for Food Sovereignty (AFSA). I have contributed to 2 books as a coauthor, and I am conference speaker, bringing stories and issues of small holder farmers to global platforms. 

I have been a Judge for the £200 000 Lush Spring Prize award, housed by Lush UK since 2017. With a role to take part in a judging and awarding process for incredible regenerative projects from around the world. 

I am one of the course instructors for Ecosystem Restoration Camps. 

I’ve been an advisor for the Regenerosity Program supporting organizations and programs in East Africa. This is a program implemented by Lush and Buckminster Fuller Institute in partnership with IKEA. 

I am continuously grateful for my upbringing by my heroic late grandmother, who stood her ground and protected the girl kids she raised from early arranged marriages of the day and a well-wishing UK based family that made me access education. I could have never known the resilience and stubbornness of hope and the great community of leaders on whose shoulders I stand.
Comments: It would be a dream to restore some of these lands away from monoculture systems to  ecorestoration systems, creating biodiversity in scale, with at least several thousand acres of mostly adjacent land. Bringing people to grow landscapes and manage ecosystems, funded by public good benefit trusts supporting long-term intergenerational skills.

Bio:
Founder, IF Insight & Foresight l Strategic Foresight Expert @European Commission & World Economic Forum l Associate Professor at ISEG - Lisbon School of Economics & Management.

Born in Lisbon, Paulo Soeiro de Carvalho is an expert in Foresight, Strategy and Innovation, with more than 20 years of experience in public and private organizations, working in several consulting projects, and also developing teaching, training and research activities in those fields.

After years of professional experience in the areas of Strategic Foresight, Innovation and Entrepreneurship, in 2018 he created "IF Insight & Foresight", a consulting studio that combines Foresight, Strategy and Innovation to create added value and distinctive experiences for organizations and professionals.

Expert and consultant for the World Economic Forum, European Commission, Joint Research Center and European Environmental Agency in the dareas of Strategic Foresight and Innovation. 

Over the last 15 years has been carrying out multiple research and academic activities, including the Coordination of Master, Post Graduation and Executive Programs in the areas of Foresight, Strategy and Innovation at the ISEG - Lisbon School of Economics and Management (University of Lisbon). From 2020 to 2023 he was the Executive Director of the ISEG MBA.

PhD in Management Sciences from the Université Jean Moulin Lyon 3 with a Thesis on Scenario Planning, Weak Signals and Competitive Intelligence. 

Paulo’s portfolio includes work with the following organisations:
Companies:
Daimler; Volkswagen; Zurich; Ranstadt; Bosch ; EDP - Energias de Portugal; GALP Energia; Sonae; Novabase; Siemens; Brisa; Celfocus; FIAT Brasil;

World Economic Forum; European Commission DG R&I, European Environmental Agency; Dubai Future Foundation; Invest Lisboa; Startup Lisboa; AICEP Portugal Global - Trade & Investment Agency; Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation; IDN – National Defense Institute (Portugal)

Bio: Regenerative Farmer
Name: Gerardo Martinez

Bio:
Did you know generating 3 centimeters of topsoil takes 1000 years? Or that soil degradation occurs at a rate of 30 soccer fields of soil every minute, primarily due to intensive farming?

The fact is 98.6% of farming practices are trapped in outdated thinking, practices, and equipment.

This translates to less than 1% of the world’s farmland being managed with regenerative farming practices. 

If these outdated practices continue, all the world’s topsoil could be gone within 60 years.

The solution? Regenerative Agriculture, which can reverse this degradation in less than 5 years. Planetary C.A.R.E. brings together farmers, suppliers, distributors, scientists, innovators, investors and advocates to realign farming practices through a member-owned cooperative.

An innovation broker, business architect, scholar, researcher, synergist and strategist, I’m passionate about the causes I invest in and dedicated to the ExO platform development that will enable acceleration of Regenerative Agriculture. 

In 2015, I initiated the concept of a multi-stakeholder collaborative network named RAIN – Regeneration in Soil Ecology. While working with Alisa Gravitz, a leader in industry change collaborative networks (the Non-GMO network and The Solar Circle), the vision became the invitation-only Carbon Farming Innovation and Supply Chain Network, of which I am founding member and a Senior Fellow.

As founder of the Health and Wellness Research Institute, we created one of the first double-blind studies with children on the autism spectrum, overseen by an institutional review board and 3 leading physicians. The study investigated the effects of the over-the-counter detoxifier Zeolite on 60 U.S. children.

Other achievements include founding the largest U.S. media placement company in its category and co-founding a counseling practice that grew from start-up to clients in 60 countries. 

To learn more, please visit https://planetarycare.org/

Bio:
Secretary/Treasurer,  Cuenca Los Ojos Foundation.
Valerie’s conservation work spans over two decades of projects focused on endangered species, water, rangeland, and wildlife habitat in the U.S. and Mexico. Most notably, Valerie spearheaded the transition of the Cuenca Los Ojos Foundation, a family foundation started by her mother, Valer Clark, to a public nonprofit that promotes land restoration both in the U.S. and Mexico. The Cuenca Los Ojos Mexico project is responsible for the management of a 121,000-acre protected preserve dedicated to restoring the historic wetlands, grasslands, and wildlife habitat of northern Mexico along the U.S./Mexico border. Valerie also served as the director of The Nature Conservancy’s Merced County Grassland’s Program where she worked to preserve a vast vernal pool grassland in California’s Central Valley in support of endangered species conservation. She also owns and operates a grass-fed, regenerative beef ranch in the eastern Sierra Nevada. Valerie’s leadership roles include chairwoman of the California Rangeland Trust, board member of both Cuenca Los Ojos in the U.S. and Mexico, technical committee member for Cuenca Los Ojos (Mexico), and board member for the Partnership of Rangeland Trusts. She is a dog lover and an avid outdoors woman who loves to trail run, backpack and ski with her husband and daughter.

Bio:
Ian Redmond OBE is an internationally renowned conservationist with more than 45 years’ experience, ranging from field research and anti-poaching to policy development with the United Nations. 
A committed conservationist and gifted communicator he is skilled and experienced in working with diverse groups towards common goals and engaging a wide range of stakeholders in core conservation issues.

CORE COMPETENCIES

Chairing / facilitating meetings and consultation groups – Ian has a track record in building consensus, resolving conflict and uniting diverse constituencies towards conservation goals. He takes special effort to encourage full participation and ensure that all parties are able to contribute through an egalitarian and positive approach. Specific roles include convening the Ape Alliance and chairing it for >25 years, playing a critical role in the establishment of the UN Great Apes Survival Partnership, and helping to develop the text of the Kinshasa Agreement on Great Apes and their Conservation (2005) and the Gorilla Agreement for the Convention on Migratory Species as well as several National Great Ape Survival Plans. 

Field missions and representation – Ian maintains a close link with on-the-ground conservation work and local communities and is experienced in conducting field visits and investigations with a range of objectives. Having started his career conducting behavioural studies on gorillas in Rwanda and elephants in Kenya, he has also led anti-poaching patrols, established monitoring programmes, undertaken undercover investigations and project evaluations. 

Communication and public speaking – a natural communicator, Ian is highly proficient in engaging a diverse array of audiences from Ladies' Luncheon Clubs to schools and universities. He has experience in helping to formulate complex conservation policies and strategies, working at both technical and ministerial level. 

Media production and engagement – Ian is a skilled publicist for conservation issues having authored 10 educational books, written and edited scientific reports and worked on more than 100 natural history and environmental documentaries for radio and television. Within the field of wildlife film making, Ian has taken professional roles including presenter, script consultant, scientific adviser, narrator, fixer and camera-man. 
His Youtube channel has had more than 31M views. To reach new audiences for important documentaries and videos he helped launch www.Ecoflix.com
Ian summarised his work in a TEDx talk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hvsWXyIseS0
Name: Ian Redmond

Name: Mary Carbajal

Bio: My study focuses on Climate and Health Nexus, Climate Change Impacts, Adaptation, Resilience, Governance and Policy. With a background in health promotion, governance and policy studies, my research focus is on policy dynamics of cross-cutting societal issues, particularly the transformation of health systems to be climate-resilient, low carbon, sustainable and equitable. I mainly work in close partnership with indigenous peoples, local communities, healthcare workers and practitioners for improving the ability of health systems to anticipate and implement adaptation intervention against climate-sensitive disease and health risks, including by bolstering climate-information services, surveillance, early warning and response systems and a climate-ready workforce.  My expertise in this area stems from my ability to work on the ground in meaningful ways with partners in government, industry, local communities and NGOs, and to connect that work to influence global policy, market and finance to advance work at scale. While working with working groups and think-tanks I convene regularly with diverse line-ministries and stakeholders to foster synergies and strengthen national and multilateral collaboration on climate change and health.
Name: Prof. Pradeep Nair

Bio:
am an agriculture graduate with the task of changing the paradigm of agriculture through soil health and an improved plant nutrition system. I have diverse extensive experience of managing large scale commercial farms as well as development projects and operations within the tight financial disciplines and budgets. I believe that the solution to the current climate crisis is under our feet, so I teach people how they can take Carbon from the atmosphere and fix it in Soil.
I am a technically-grounded agronomist with experience in all aspects of crop production. My areas of specialization include horticulture crops value chain development, composting, inorganic and organic nutrient management, plant-soil nutrient cycling and sustainable management and control techniques for soil diseases, nematodes and weeds in conventional and organic crop production. One of my main responsibilities is to educate people on Soil, Climate and Biodiversity connection. I am also teaching Climate Smart Agriculture practices to the Refugees of the Nakivale Camp in the Southwest of Uganda.

Bio:

Bio:
Director- GOGREENLOCALLY.ORG- Local Green Online Hubs- Directories, Virtual Tours, and Newsletters - Eco-Action Initiative Resources & Links - Purpose, Connections & Resources for Action!

Founder of GOGREENLOCALLY.ORG. -501c3 nonprofit. GGL provides an online community sharing hubs of resources for locals taking on all types of people and planet-friendly action. 

At each of the 60 hubs individuals can share or add to six directories covering local events, businesses, groups, nonprofit initiatives, promotions, support, and online resources. All community events and promotions are shared to help the community stay abreast of everything going on locally. 

GGL promotes local groups, nonprofits, and businesses that locals can connect with, support, and join. Promotions are done through social media and local podcast show interviews.

GoGreenLocally is more than a green directory. It's a vibrant community of like-minded people. We are working to combat hopelessness, apathy, and inaction by empowering people everywhere to take small steps leading to big change.

We encourage stronger reliance on local natural food systems, services, and goods. We are motivated by the simple belief that when small communities form tighter circular economies, they grow stronger, healthier, and safer from the fluctuations and polluting of global economies. 

We have one national podcast:
-"Locals Share Green Action" podcast that promotes and shares the how-to work of local residents across the US taking solution-based action https://www.gogreenlocally.org/podcast

We have multiple local podcasts available at each local hub sharing local groups, nonprofits, and businesses that are providing things that locals might want to support, join, or collaborate with.

Our local business directory listings allow people to share green-certified and non-certified small sustainable locally-serving businesses. Green-certified businesses get a directory badge of honor, and notation of the name of the certifying agency/company, and a link to their certifying agency's directory so you can verify their status and what they had to do to achieve it. This helps to aggregate the great work that multiple agencies are doing to support businesses and give those businesses more exposure to people who can truly appreciate and support their work. Contact info@GoGreenLocally.org to provide certification links if your listed business is certified. We'll make sure the certification is added.

Bio:
Do you have a project involving community agriculture/ agroforestry, ecological restoration, green infrastructure, or watershed management?

My team designs and plans projects that provide for people while aligning with natural principals and processes.

Our design process focuses on: 
1) Understanding the needs of the stakeholders
2) Understanding the site conditions 
3) Combining global knowledge and experience with local expertise
4) Providing a design and implementation plan appropriate for the people, the site, and the budget 
5) The result is a design that provides for human needs while restoring ecological function and health 


Education is an important component of ecological regeneration.

We offer training for land owners, managers, and contractors for design implementation, care, and maintenance.

I also offer stand alone public speaking and education. 

If you think I can be of help for your project, please dm me or check us out at easternecosystems.com & uniteddesigners.org

Bio:
Moussa Kondo, Former Special Advisor to the President of the Republic of Mali in charge of governance, democracy and rule of law, Moussa has worked extensively also on international relations at the Presidency of Mali before he resigns for personal reasons.
Moussa is a journalist and civil society actor in Mali with close to 20 years of experience in various areas of community development, particularly in youth engagement and civic participation. 
Founder of the weekly newspaper L' Express de Bamako, Moussa also founded and directed Accountability Lab Mali until his appointment to the Presidency of Mali. 
He contributes to sustainable development by educating youth in leadership, promoting accountability, governance, honesty and integrity in public service. Some of the participants in his program have obtained key positions in various organizations such as the World Bank, UNDP, IOM etc. 
After his master's degree from the University of Bamako and his community service experiences, Moussa was selected as one of 500 young African leaders in 2015 for the Mandela Washington Fellowship of the U.S. Government's Young African Leaders Initiative (YALI) in Business and Entrepreneurship at Dartmouth College, an Ivy League institution based in New Hampshire, USA. 
Selected as a 2018 Obama Fellow out of more than 24,000 applications, Moussa was also selected as one of the Draper Hills Fellows, to study Democracy, Development and the Rule of Law at Stanford University in California, USA.
Beyond his country, Moussa is a fixture on the continent through his role as Chair of the APRM Youth Network, an African Union institution based in Johannesburg and the President of the Progressive African Network initiated by former President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria. 
before opening the Accountability Lab office in Mali and he is expanding it now in the rest of Francophone Africa. 2018 Obama Fellow, Moussa has been also selected among the Draper Hills Fellows to study Democracy and Rule of Law at Stanford University.

Bio:
Environmentalist and Data Analyst
Vetiver sans frontières  Université Laval

At Vetiver Without Borders (VSF), our mission is clear: to champion environmental regeneration and empower communities to thrive in the face of climate change. We believe in the power of the Vetiver System, a sustainable and cost-effective solution that addresses critical issues such as soil erosion, rainwater management, and the overall impact of climate change.

Our Mission:
We're dedicated to supporting communities worldwide in their journey towards resilience. Our goal is to make the Vetiver System accessible and to harness its potential for positive change. By partnering with local organizations, businesses, and passionate individuals, we're cultivating a greener, more sustainable future for all.

Our Services:

Innovation and Research: We're at the forefront of environmental regeneration techniques, continuously seeking innovative methods to combat the challenges posed by climate change.
Technical Support: Our team of experts provides guidance and technical support to ensure the successful implementation of Vetiver-based projects.
Natural Disaster Relief: We respond swiftly to environmental crises, offering assistance and solutions to communities in need.
Climate Change Adaptation: Our initiatives are designed to help communities adapt to the changing climate, fostering resilience and sustainability.
Join us in our mission to rejuvenate the Earth, one seed at a time. Together, we can create a lasting impact on the environment and the communities that depend on it.
Name: Nabil Chaib Draa

Bio:
Time to stop being small - it is the planet that is calling and I can't think of anything more fun than discovering how to live in ways that make our home, our planet thrive. Actually becoming regenerative in our thoughts and actions makes our caring for LIFE visible. New kinds of business, new business practices, new commitments to loving life are beckoning. Shifting leadership styles, expanding our capacity to be adaptable are clear steps forward. Let's go!

Conversational Intelligence® offers a way to make the shift from pushing ideas on others, to creating real partnerships that are mutually satisfying. We, as humans, are hard wired for two things: self-protection and connection. The way we talk to others generates either one or the other. All too often we make people uneasy with the power of our passion and they react by protecting themselves through resistance, even if they might actually agree. It is my job to shift that, to shift my clients experience from on of experiencing resistance to one of collaboration. Conversational Intelligence® offers the tools and processes to make that happen. Get coached!

Specialties: Helping leaders create cultures that work!

Bio:
Planet Repair, Equality & Global Alliance Maverick.  I am an International strategy, economics, politics and environmental specialist focusing on building more equitable, efficient and democratic societies by addressing the complex issues in the global political economy. I get excited by working with talented and fun teams that allow me to follow my passions for learning and growing while building alliances that formulate and scale-up resilient solutions that achieve the UN SDGs. The areas I enjoy working on the most are governance, ethics, inequality, climate action, sustainability, technology, media and human rights.

As the Founder of Blue-Green Futures, I consult climate-focused alliances, NGOs and entrepreneurial teams. Blue-Green Futures aims to help people accelerate strategic planning, communities and blended finance for nature-based solutions, eco-industrial climate tech and human well-being. Some of my favorite solutions are carbon negative concrete, regenerative agriculture/aquaculture, agroforestry, carbon utilisation and renewable energy. Previously, I developed international projects and research at the United Nations UNICRI Centre for AI & Robotics. I directly supported Irakli Beridze in developing the organisation and its various activities. Our team significantly advanced action-oriented engagement on research, projects and governance frameworks that concentrated on the ethical, legal, social and security implications of how AI and other advanced technologies are utilised by criminals, terrorists and stakeholders in security. 

Education, empathy, curiosity and intrinsic motivation are what I value most in life. All excellent leaders and strategies that produce high-quality results require concentrating on education, human potential, ecological/human health and trust. At Leiden University, where I received my master’s in International Relations, I enjoyed my academic journey and advancing the experiences of my classmates by serving as the President of the International Studies Student Association. 

Earlier, in America, I followed my love to improve education by working at Tufts University for senior research admin officials and departments to manage their communications, PR and university-wide strategic planning initiatives. I also have professional media and marketing experiences, like helping the VICE Media marketing team establish their new TV Channel, VICELAND.

Bio:
Mother, Rancher, Author, Naturalist. Owner and operator (with her husband and four children) of Markegard Family Grass-Fed LLC. 
 
Doniga has a background in nature and permaculture. This has given her a perspective on the real risks that we are facing as a species. In her youth she was mentored by some of the leading wildlife trackers, naturalists and Native spiritual elders. She spent years alone and with a small group of passionate youth in the Western Washington Wilderness learning the ways of the ancestors, immersing in nature, bird language, survival skills and wildlife tracking.

​Along with her husband and four children, Doniga owns and operates Markegard Family Grass-Fed LLC raising grass-fed beef, lamb, pastured pork, chicken and dairy supplying the Bay Area with local, nutrient dense foods. The family ranch leases land through out the Bay Area spanning over 10,000 acres. 

She is dedicated to finding ways to regenerate lands and community through ranching practices that build soil, sequester carbon, capture and purify water and enhance habitat.

Bio:
Independent Publishing Professional.

Judith D. Schwartz is an author who tells stories to explore and illuminate scientific concepts and cultural nuance. She takes a clear-eyed look at global environmental, economic, and social challenges, and finds insights and solutions in natural systems. She writes for numerous publications, including The American Prospect, The Guardian, Discover, Scientific American, and YaleE360. Her latest book, “The Reindeer Chronicles”, is a global tour of earth repair, featuring stops in Norway, Spain, Hawai’i, New Mexico, and beyond. 

Judy has a B.A. from Brown University, an M.S.J. from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, and an M.A. in Counseling Psychology from Northwestern. She lives and works on the side of a mountain in Vermont with her husband, author Tony Eprile, and cherishes visits from their musician son, Brendan. When it snows, she cross-country skis, and when ski season is over, she’s in the garden. Three times a week she trains in Uechi-Ryu karate, and has reached the rank of shodan. 

Books: Cows Save the Planet and Other Improbable Ways of Restoring Soil to Heal the Earth (Chelsea Green, 2013); Water In Plain Sight: Hope for a Thirsty World (St. Martin's Press, 2016; Chelsea Green, 2019); The Reindeer Chronicles and Other Inspiring Stories of Working With Nature to Heal the Earth (Chelsea Green, 2020)
Name: Judith Schwartz
updates: Posting: not allowed  ||  Email Pref: not allowed

Bio:
Viridis Terra is a Canadian green-tech company specialized in the restoration and return into production of degraded lands, including mine sites, to face the global problem of land degradation, disappearance of biodiversity, in addition to fighting climate change. 

The company has developed an innovative technological and managerial package for large-scale integrated forest and agroforest landscape restoration (IFLR®). This package increases, by two to three times, land and tree productivity compared to traditional technologies while ensuring sustainability, reducing operation costs, creating new livelihoods and revenue streams for landholders and local communities, and allowing to scale-up and carry out activities effectively at a very large-scale and in transparent way. 

The package includes our own Viridis Terra field-based patent-pending biotechnologies for the restoration of natural forests, hi-tech tree factory for the production of high-quality seedlings for commercial purposes, biotech lab for the production of biofertilizers, and plant micropropagation by somatic embryogenesis, remote sensing and geo-traceability technologies, in addition to our digital blockchain-based platform called TreesOfLives®, which plays three important functions: an impact investment vehicle in our projects, a project operation data management system, and a system for the sale of project outputs (certified timber, agri-food, energy wood, offsets, etc.). 
The business model allows us to transform the cost of restoration and reforestation into an investment that generates returns for the investors through time. 

Viridis Terra currently has operations in Canada, the Caribbean, Latin America, and West Africa.
Name: Marc-André Coulombe

Bio:
Ambassador at Commonland and Chairman of the Advisory Board for the ERC/Commonland Foundation.

After 15 years as a Television Producer and Cameraman for CBS News, RAI and ZDF John began to study ecology. In the mid-1990’s he began a participatory process with a number of media and broadcasting colleagues in Beijing that led to the creation of the Environmental Education Media Project for China (EEMPC). He has directed the EEMPC (now the EEMP) from its beginning. The EEMPC has distributed over 1000 environmental films in China since then. The EEMPC also helped found the “China Environment and Sustainable Development Reference and Research Center (CESDRRC) and the China HIV/AIDS Information Center (CHAIN). Over the years their activities have broadened beyond China to include the entire world and to include the production of environmental and ecological films. The name was shortened to Environmental Education Media Project (EEMP) when they were asked to work in other countries. From 2003 – 2006 John was a visiting fellow with the Faculty of Natural Sciences and the Faculty of the Built Environment at the University of the West of England, In 2006 he was named the Rothamsted International Fellow for the Communication of Science, from 2010 – 2013 John was a Senior Research Fellow for IUCN. In 2013 he received the Communications Award from the Society for Ecological Restoration (SER), “Green Gold” a film about his work produced by the VPRO won a Prix Italia award. “Hope in a Changing Climate” was named the best ecosystem film by the International Wildlife Film Festival and won several other honors. He currently also serves as ambassador for the Commonland Foundation.

Bio:
I am dedicated to strategically steering our planetary future towards resilience and sustainability, particularly focusing on the global South. My mission is to harness the power of research as public goods to drive impactful change.
With a diverse background spanning multiple sectors, I am dedicated to strategically steering our planetary future towards resilience and sustainability in my role at CIFOR-ICRAF. Particularly focused on the global South, my mission is to harness the power of research as public goods to drive impactful change.

Currently, my efforts are concentrated on building a digital commons that serves as a public good for shared knowledge and innovation. This initiative aims to foster equitable, thoughtful, and evidence-based innovations and technologies that promote effective climate action, food security, and biodiversity.

My work emphasizes integrating emerging technology governance with indigenous wisdom and women-led perspectives, ensuring that solutions are equitable and responsibly designed. My experiences at the Regen Foundation and P2P Foundation have reinforced my commitment to digital equity, climate justice, and the stewardship of the Commons.

I am passionate about fostering multi-sectoral collaborations, creating public goods across food systems, agriculture, and climate ecosystems. I strive to align private sector innovation and policy-making with evidence-based practices while ensuring community and digital equity.

If you share a vision for collaborative public goods and sustainable innovation, I invite you to connect. Let's explore how we can work together to make a meaningful impact.

Feel free to message me or schedule a chat here: https://revathi.me

Name: Celia Francis

Bio: Over the past two decades, I have been leading technical projects worldwide that can transform the way we connect to marine environments as the Executive Director at The Climate Foundation. As a Hertz and Edmund Hillary Fellow, and a co-founder and board member of several organizations focusing on renewable energy storage, climate change, and ecosystem regeneration, my mission is to develop and scale nature-based solutions that can restore the health and productivity of the oceans, while providing food security, carbon sequestration, and biodiversity benefits that our global civilization will need to become sustainable. I have pioneered the concept and practice of Marine Permaculture, which involves restoring natural upwelling and regenerating thousands of square kilometers of lost kelp forests. I bring a diverse and interdisciplinary background in planetary science, computer science, electronics, FPGA design, video processing, and intellectual property development to this innovative and impactful work.

Bio:
Associate Professor Jan Pokorný  works in the field of environmental protection.  He has extensive experience in cooperation with foreign and domestic research entities. During his time at the Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic, he participated in the development of instrumentation for
measuring oxygen concentration and photosynthesis, and later initiated the development of a suction dredger for the restoration of eutrophic reservoirs. He is the author of 250 original scientific publications. In 1998, he was one of the founders of ENKI, ops, which is the bearer of research and development activities of the Science and Technology Park - Tÿeboÿ Innovation Center. Jan Pokorný has been the director of this company since its
establishment. The company combines technological and scientific approaches to the solution of post-mining
landscape restoration projects, renewable resources, links between agricultural and pond farming and solves
applied and basic research projects, MIT (Prosperity) and EU FP6 (East Africa) projects.

Bio: Andrei Nefiodov graduated from Leningrad (now St. Petersburg) State University, Faculty of Physics, Theoretical Physics Department, in 1988 and obtained his PhD in theoretical physics from St. Petersburg State University in 1991. Since 1992, he has been working in the Theoretical Physics Division at Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute. The field of research included the study of structure and dynamics of highly charged ions, both within the framework of QED theory and beyond it, in particular, taking into account the nuclear and weak interactions. Together with Dr. Vladimir Ovsyannikov he suggested novel method for the production of highly charged ions, which was realized in ion source of the next generation. Since 2011 he joined Prof. Victor Gorshkov and Dr. Anastassia Makarieva in development of the condensational theory of hurricanes, which represents the physical mechanism of biotic pump theory. Recent activity is focused on the natural ecosystem's control of the water cycle and moisture transport.

Bio:

Name: Marie Pierre Bilodeau

Bio:
Renew Land and Water: Partnering with Nature to Create Vibrant Landscapes. Partnering with nature to restore healthy vibrant landscapes that support the conditions for all life to flourish. 

The way that land is managed directly affects the ability for the soil to absorb and retain water; this in turn affects the severity of floods, fires, and droughts. It influences where, when, and how it rains. The conditions that cause dehydration and degradation can be reversed by changing the way we manage our land and water. We can see tangible results in a matter of years.

We can steward the land in ways that: 
▪ Mitigate flooding
▪ Reduce the extent and severity of fires
▪ Develop resilience to drought
▪ Recharge depleted groundwater
▪ Increase stream flows in low-water season
▪ Improve water quality

Bio:
Sustainability Practitioner | ESG Advisor | Consultative Selling B2B Business Dev.| Partnership Builder | Stewardship/Risk Mitigation | I help cities/corps. find solutions to drive on-the-ground sustainability actions.

The Climate PI (planetary intelligence) 

I became interested in science and the environment from an early age. I have innate empathy for all creatures and have always been curious about the environment and enthusiastic about science. 

While I was earning my degree at McGill in Environmental Studies and Biology, I read Al Gore's first book Earth in Balance.....a precursor to his award winning Inconvenient Truth. That’s when it hit me that nature and all of earth's species didn't have any rights, and pollution was killing everything slowly, including people. I believe the natural environment and people are interdependent and am dedicated to working towards achieving growth without further harm.

As a result, early in my career I became very passionate about finding roles that use/monetize science. I sold hands on science experiences at Mad Science, where I ran the Montreal headquarters including sales, recruiting, accounting, and customer service. At the Institute for International Research (IIR), executive training company, I ran the sales department, and enjoyed motivating my enterprise, inside and telesales teams to be successful client centric sells consultants while learning about new verticals such as Tech, Mining and Pharma. 

After taking several years off to raise my family, during which I was an active Board Chair at their school, I was eager to rejoin the workforce. In 2020, I took a position as Co-founder and Strategic Partnership Officer at Climate Pi, an early-stage start-up aggregating climate best practices/tools/data, enabling cities around the world to track, measure, and scale emission reductions. There I’ve rapidly built an active network of data and funding partners from the ground up and have an 80% close rate securing city/corporate participation.

Last year, to broaden my knowledge on latest in climate, I completed the Terra.do Learning for Action fellowship and was asked to stay on as a Community Ambassador hosting online programs for executives looking to learn more about the climate space. 

I also currently serve as Senior Fellow with Global Urban Development, a global think tank, where I work with over 500 high-profile urban leaders around the globe to educate and contribute to the research and success of climate innovation zones.

Bio:
Jon Schull is co-Founder and President of the EcoRestoration Alliance. 
 
A biological psychologist, entrepreneur, human-computer interaction researcher and digital community organizer, Dr. Jon Schull is the founder of e-NABLE, an online philanthropic community that makes free open-source 3D-printed prosthetic hands and arms for children and adults with upper limb differences. Concerned about the climate crisis, and impressed by the recent recognition that restoration of degraded habitats could literally cool the planet by 1 degree C within 10 years, Schull is now attempting to apply the “distributed do-ocracy” processes pioneered by e-NABLE to the problem of climate change. During the summer of 2021 he founded the EcoRestoration Alliance to build a collaboration of scientists and regenerative activists to bring earth-restoring practices front and center in the climate and biodiversity conversations, and to apply for funding supplied by the XPRIZE Carbon Removal competition.

Name: Joe Morris

Bio:
Creator at Water Stories, Owner at Elemental Ecosystems. 

Zach is the protégé of revolutionary Austrian farmer Sepp Holzer. He is the first and only person to earn a Holzer Practitioner certification directly from Sepp - through a rigorous two-year apprenticeship. After learning from Sepp, he set out to create Elemental Ecosystems, a business that provides an action-oriented process to improve clients' relationship with their landscape.

Elemental Ecosystems is an ecological development contracting and consulting company specializing in watershed restoration and ecosystem regeneration. Harvesting time and the productivity of natural systems is the guiding principle - resulting in abundant oases with the potential to last until the next ice age. Elemental Ecosystems has worked in 25 countries, on 6 continents, spanning a wide range of climates, contexts, landforms, and ecosystems. 

After 10 years of doing projects for Elemental Ecosystems, Zach began to see the limits of his availability and need for water retention work at scale, and thus felt a call to share this knowledge with others. This is where Water Stories was born.

Bio:
Our project, the Nature-based Solutions (NbS) and Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA) Center, located in the Guidimakha region of Mauritania, aims to restore degraded ecosystems while strengthening the climate resilience of rural communities. We implement sustainable, integrated practices to address climate change challenges through land restoration, agroforestry, and the sustainable management of natural resources.

We contribute to biosphere restoration in a holistic way by:

- Restoring degraded lands: We aim to restore 1,000 hectares of degraded agricultural and forest land through reforestation, soil management, and agroecology.
- Promoting biodiversity: Our ecological restoration practices, such as Forest Landscape - - 
- Restoration (FLR), enhance local biodiversity while increasing ecosystem resilience to climate-related disasters.
- Carbon sequestration: By integrating solutions such as agroforestry and reforestation, we help sequester carbon, contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions (EbM – Ecosystem-based Mitigation).
- Supporting local communities: We work closely with local farmers and cooperatives to promote practices that not only restore the environment but also improve their livelihoods, creating a circular and sustainable economy.

We believe that our initiative should be highlighted on your map as it aligns perfectly with ERA's mission: promoting nature-based solutions that are practical, affordable, effective, and centered on community empowerment. Additionally, our approach actively involves indigenous and rural communities, strengthening both the ecological and economic resilience of a vulnerable region.

Bio:
CEO, GoodCarts New customers for purpose-driven brands
Ashoka Fellow
White House Champion of Change (Obama)

I change the world one action at a time. Step by step. Person by person. Day by day. Today, my impact is all about this formula:

Sustainability + Shop for Good + Underrepresented Small Business x Tech for Good + Retail/E-commerce x Digital Outreach & Marketing x Social Entrepreneurship = My startup CEO role at GoodCarts.co

My impact backstory ...

I help people with big ideas connect with the lessons, leaders, and networks they need to succeed.

I have unparalleled 30+ years of direct experience across 35+ nations with digital c
impact and innovation with business, government, foundations and nonprofits. 

I am @democracy on Twitter.

In 2013, I was honored by the White House as a Champion of Change for Open Government. In 2006, I became an Ashoka Fellow. 

Back in 1994, I launched E-Democracy.org – the world’s first election information website at age 25. During that time my “government by day, citizen by night” insights were built as leader of the State of Minnesota’s first e-government initiative. 

Upon leaving my "day job"​ in government to pursue my passion with building stronger communities and better democracies online, I starting speaking and consulting globally to support non-partisan, volunteer-powered efforts for inclusive online citizen participation through E-Democracy. From Estonia and Libya to Mongolia and most recently Chile and Taiwan, I've spoken on open government, civic technology, digital democracy, and inclusive online community engagement and citizen participation across 35+ countries.

After subsidizing the non-profit E-Democracy for a decade fueled by passion and my time, I worked full-time for E-Democracy from 2009-2015 based on grant resources we attracted for our experimental civic work. I now lead E-Democracy on a volunteer basis as Board President.

My app "side hustle," 1 Radio News is now nearly ten years old with 200,000 downloads on Android. My newer TV News app is now out and rocketed to 2M downloads and in now on iOS as "TV News Channels." Try it out. I do a bit of app strategy on the side for others as well and can connect you with my developer partner.

Name: Sev Clarke

Bio:
A medical doctor turned social entrepreneur, I lead Hagush, a nonprofit social enterprise focused on creating a just and inclusive economy.

People often ask why I left clinical medicine, and why the shift to economics.

Here's why: 

1. I have a knack for creative problem-solving, a skill that is not particularly useful in clinical medicine where protocols and guidelines largely govern practice. In medicine, you do what is proven to work or the next best thing — and for good reason. The stakes are simply too high for anything else. 

2. I’m bothered by this: widespread progress these days feels like a pipe dream. How is it that we still live in a world where vaccine apartheid is a thing and almost a third of the world’s population lives offline. I am convinced that we need more innovation in the civic and social spheres to reimagine and rebuild our social systems and ensure that human ingenuity, first and foremost, serves the public good. 

3. I don’t believe the solution to the myriad of problems in my part of the world, Africa, lies in creating low-cost versions of sleek Global North technologies or deploying clever, if ad hoc, workaround fixes. Such approaches are absolutely necessary on some level, but ultimately, we do need to address the systems and structures that create and perpetuate poverty. We must redress the laws and institutions that reinforce global economic inequality. To do that, I have found the best place to start is to understand the status quo, which has meant that I make a hard pivot from medicine to economics (this, I did *NOT* see coming — but here we are).

Now, my work in global development is informed by economic history, focusing on understanding the structural dimensions of inequality in the global economy, the role of the state in development, rethinking the workings of the third sector and designing and implementing solutions to advance the SDGs. 

You can check out what we're up to at Hagush, where we're building cost-effective, sustainable, and scalable development solutions while exploring pathways to systemic and structural change anchored on building a world where everyone can and will do well.
Name: Nadait Gebremedhen

Bio:
Using my patented Combined Remediation Biomass and Bio-Product Production (CRBBP) Process and my other patent-pending processes, we plant the fastest and largest-growing Bio-Crops we can find, and use Photosynthesis, one of nature's oldest CO 2 capture processes, to capture optimal and large amounts of atmospheric CO 2/Acre/Time Period, to combat Climate Change, at one of the world’s lowest costs ($35/Ton).  

We then convert the resulting Climate-Smart plant material (Biomass) into a variety of Climate-Smart Bio-Products, to sequester captured Carbon for very long, or varying periods of time.

And the Bio-Crops we use can also remediate and enhance air, soils and water, and provide other environmental services, and such multi-tasking can make each CRBBP Process task, including CO 2 capture, even less expensive, due to my CRBBP Process' cost-sharing feature.

In one of our first initiatives, we have begun partnering with utilities in CRBBP Process Demo Projects, where we are planting Biomass Sorghum on their underutilized sites, then converting the resulting Biomass into Climate-Smart Biochar and embedding it in those sites, to long-term sequester the captured Carbon, with the intention of earning Carbon Credits.  

We are already in touch with other, land-rich businesses, entities and governments to explore a similar approach.

Also, as it relates to making other Climate-Smart Bio-Products, we have collaborated with a university to convert Biomass Sorghum into a Climate-Smart Coating, which protects military vehicles from chemical warfare.

And, as you may know, Carbon Black is made by converting raw oil into what is, unfortunately, a very toxic Filler Powder, commonly used in making composites, plastics and makes up about 30% of the composition of tires.  We are commercializing a patent-pending, safer, more sustainable and Climate-Smart, Bio-Based Filler Powder alternative.  

In support of this effort, we were honored to be among the first 16 grantees of the US Government's BioMADE Program, which seeks to create a new Bio-Economy.

See: https://www.biomade.org

Again, I am hoping that we might collaborate with you, and your organization, in a variety of Climate Change Mitigation, Environmental Remediation, Environmental Justice and Bio-Product initiatives.

I look forward to your reply.

Regards,

Joe

Name: Joe James

Bio:
I've dedicated my life and career to solving problems, starting from humble beginnings like picking stones and baling hay in farm fields to mastering the art of transforming rotary engine cars in garages. At the age of 22, I ventured into entrepreneurship, building a multi-million dollar advertising agency over a decade. After successfully selling the business to a New York holding company, my trajectory shifted as I joined the M&A team, contributing to the acquisition of 19 companies within three years.

While continuing to build and advise various ventures, I recognized that there are monumental global challenges demanding attention, such as Climate Change, World Hunger, and the imperative for a healthier planet. Motivated by a desire to make a substantial impact, I took part in commercializing and scaling a groundbreaking biotechnology company.

This journey unveiled a crucial realization—the necessity for a circular project development company capable of rapidly constructing large-scale, impactful technology projects worldwide. Fueled by a sense of urgency, given the staggering number of people facing starvation daily and the alarming pace of climate change, I founded Orbital Farm in 2018.

Today, Orbital Farm is actively engaged in building closed-loop systems with the potential to produce vaccines, medicines, hydrogen energy, and food on a global scale, using water, CO2, and electricity as primary resources. Our vision extends to establishing 200 circular mega projects across the planet, aiming to support and nourish billions of people on Earth while dedicating the next two decades to prototyping and developing technology for future space exploration.

For me, Orbital Farm isn't just a business; it's my life's work, my dream, and my purpose—a commitment to creating a sustainable and transformative future.
Name: Scot Bryson

Bio:
Executive Director, Mother Tree Food & Forest
Director, EcoRestoration Alliance
Director, School of Constructive Arts
I began Life in the Oklahoma Seminole Nation. I have practiced organic gardening since childhood, organic farming for much of my adult Life, and regenerative horticulture, food forestry, and wildland restoration for the last decade. The studies and practices which inform my agroecology and ecorestoration thought and work (research, practice, and education) include western science soil biology/ecology; many realms of mycology, botany, ecology, and zoology; ecological anthropology and history; ethnobotany; herbalism; plant/fungi medicine work; “conventional” regenerative agriculture; ancient Indigenous agroecology and ecological land management sciences; landscape water retention; wetland restoration; syntropic agroforestry; food forestry; desert reforestation; Miyawaki reforestation; and ecology/climate physics (including Biotic Pump Theory). I integrate these western science studies, modern agroecology and ecorestoration practices, indigenous agroecology traditions and TEK, anthropogenic landscape studies, food/medicine work, and ecological history into a coherent picture of what human relationship with Earth looks like when we act as a steward species. My studies and practices focus on helping people meet their needs while restoring ecosystems and stabilizing global climate. I live in the Mimbres watershed near the Gila wilderness area, in the most northern range of the Chihuahua desert, in the unceded lands of the living Chiricahua peoples, of the Brown Bear, of the Jaguar, of the Beaver, and of the Forests and Wetlands which stood there 400 years ago. #eraboard

Bio:
Born amidst the vibrant rhythms of Martinique, I embarked on a digital odyssey at a young age, captivated by the nascent internet. Fast forward to USC, where I honed my expertise in computer science, weaving stories into pixels not in Silicon Valley, but at the heart of imagination: Disney Interactive in Burbank and Glendale. While exciting, the tech whirlwind lacked a certain groundedness. Witnessing the toll on personal well-being, I sought a different rhythm, one attuned to the ancient wisdom of Eastern medicine.

This quest led me to Houston's American College of Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine, where I traded lines of code for the delicate dance of needles and biocircuitry. My focus on Men's Health stemmed from seeing the correlation between the tech industry's frenetic pace and a disconnect from nature.

Today, I wear two hats: a doctor of acupuncture and Eastern medicine and a tech-savvy advocate for holistic well-being. Drawing on my unique background, I help individuals navigate the modern world without losing their inner compass.

My guiding principles:

Harmonizing technology and nature: Technology is a powerful tool, but it's vital to integrate it with the grounding influence of nature. By incorporating principles of the five elements (wood, fire, earth, metal, water) into daily routines, we create balance and restore vital energy.
Reconnecting with the body: Beyond pixels and screens, lies the intricate network of the human body. Acupuncture offers a bridge to understanding and optimizing this internal ecosystem, promoting deeper self-awareness and resilience.

Holistic wellness: True well-being encompasses mind, body, and spirit. By integrating Eastern wisdom with modern tools, I support individuals in creating sustainable, personalized wellness plans that empower them to thrive.

Whether you're a tech executive seeking balance, or simply yearning for a more grounded approach to life, I invite you to connect and explore the possibilities of harmonizing technology and nature for optimal health and well-being.

The Andhra Pradesh Community Managed Natural Farming Movement grew from 40,000 farmers in 2016 to almost 800,000 farmers in 2020 in one of the driest states in India. Its success is due in large part to a community-supported approach where women-managed Self Help Groups are in charge of operations. Vijay Kumar, who is the Agriculture and Cooperation Advisor to the government of Andhra Pradesh, India, directs the implementation of natural farming in the state, and has dedicated years to agricultural projects that empower communities and alleviate poverty. Vijay acknowledges the impact of Australian soil microbiologist Walter Jehne’s ideas for increasing drought resilience.

Bio:
What kind of future do we want?

How do we get there?

What actions can we take now to activate an economy that partners with the earth to nurture human development?

If you’re passionate about shaping a future that is socially, environmentally, and financially sound for your children and grandchildren, these questions very likely probe your brain daily. 

I have good news: 

Solutions are all around us. One of the most promising solutions is agroforestry. 

Agroforestry is the intentional integration of trees into agricultural landscapes to establish regenerative, self-reinforcing and productive crop and animal farming ecosystems. 

With an ecological crisis that can be seen on many fronts, it’s simply a necessity to take action in applying these systems to large-scale farming.

At the same time, the demand for nutrient-dense food is greater now than ever. Providing a business opportunity that solves ecological problems while meeting society’s need for quality food.

Pulling from expertise in agroforestry, regenerative land management, farm business and finance, our team offers a triple bottom line investment opportunity.

We have a proven capacity to implement solutions. Now we seek capital partners to realize them on a larger scale.

If your purpose is to make a lasting difference, and you want to learn more about the compounding benefits of this opportunity (for you, for us, for the people, and for the planet), then let’s chat!

Bio: Charles Eisenstein is an author, speaker, and cultural philosopher whose books—including Sacred Economics (2011), The More Beautiful World Our Hearts Know Is Possible (2013), and Climate: A New Story (2018)—explore themes of ecological interconnection, gift economics, and the transition from separation to interbeing. A Yale graduate in Mathematics and Philosophy, Eisenstein challenges conventional narratives around money, growth, and climate change, proposing that our environmental crisis stems from viewing nature as separate from ourselves rather than sacred and inherently valuable. His work advocates for economic degrowth, gift economy principles, and reframing our relationship with the living world beyond carbon metrics and instrumental value.
Name: Charles Eisenstein

Bio:
Roland Bunch, PhD
Leader in Regenerative Land Management

Roland Bunch, PhD, of The Center for Regenerative Agriculture and Resilient Systems, is one of the most well-respected and honored leaders in regenerative land management, both in terms of food security and addressing ecological degradation and climate disruption. He has worked as a consultant in sustainable agricultural development for over 40 NGOs and governments in 50 nations. The second of his four books, “Two Ears of Corn, A Guide to People-Centered Agricultural Improvement,” is a best-seller on agricultural development programs in developing nations. In 1983, Dr. Bunch began investigating the use of plants for regenerating the soil, which he calls “green manure/cover crops.” Through his Better Soils - Better Lives initiative, his goal is to double the agricultural productivity of 70% of Sub-Saharan farmers in twenty years and thereby end hunger. His confidence is based on the successful implementation of regenerative principles there and by millions of farmers across the world.

Relevant Articles:
Restoring the Soil: A Guide for Using Green Manure/Cover Crops to Improve the Food Security of Smallholder Farmers
Two Ears of Corn, A Guide to People-Centered Agricultural Improvement
Name: Roland Bunch

Bio:
Symbiotic AI change agent with a background in Computer Science & Engineering, Artificial intelligence, Leadership for Sustainability, Podcasting, Business Development and Systems Thinking.

Having lived as an expat and immigrant for over 10 years, I had to quickly learn the systems and narratives that govern our world. For me, it wasn’t a matter of luxury, but a need for survival. Out of this journey, I understood the power that organizations and individuals have to develop a better world, but also the struggles both of them face to do so! That’s why I dedicate my time to helping organizations and individuals to lead the present and pioneer a sustainable and inclusive future! 

I am at my happiest when I am coming up with solutions with people, discussing ideas, solving problems or when I can touch a person's heart. My mind is a problem-solving machine that can analyse information from many different sources to form a solution. Like a conductor in an orchestra, I understand each instrument, its strengths and weaknesses and I find a way to use them together in a harmonious way. This allows me to excel at creative tasks and problem-solving but hinders me when doing rudimentary work. I am a person who meditates often and is in touch with its emotions, therefore I value healthy relationships and open communication.

My purpose in life is to use my unyielding drive to reflect, learn and grow from all my experiences in order to use my resources, wisdom, and love to cultivate and develop authentic, loving, and inspiring relationships, communities, and solutions aimed at the creation of a sustainable world where people feel accepted, supported, empowered, loved and included. Bio:
Paul Chatterton is the Lead and Founder of the Landscape Finance Lab, a groundbreaking global platform dedicated to incubating and financing sustainable landscapes. Launched in 2021 as a spin-off from WWF, the Lab pioneers innovative solutions to address complex landscape challenges, supported by a global network of experts.

A recognized leader in sustainability, climate, land use and green finance, Paul has spearheaded transformative initiatives including two of the world’s largest forest carbon programs, Europe’s longest river protected area, the largest rainforest reserve in the Pacific and financing platforms for peatland restoration in the UK and Ireland.

Paul co-authored The Little Sustainable Landscape Book and co-initiated Meridia (www.meridia.land), a cutting-edge mobile app providing affordable land tenure solutions for rural communities.

He has advised high-profile organizations such as the Climate Bonds Initiative, Gold Standard Foundation, World Economic Forum, EU Sustainable Finance Taxonomy and the Forest Stewardship Council, shaping policies and strategies at the forefront of sustainability.

Paul holds a Master’s degree with Merit in Anthropology and Development Studies from Sydney University and a Diploma in Management from IMD Business School in Switzerland.Paul Chatterton is the Lead and Founder of the Landscape Finance Lab, a groundbreaking global platform dedicated to incubating and financing sustainable landscapes. Bio:

He has a proven knack for spotting and nurturing new opportunities, particularly those demanding a high degree of creativity, imagination and dedication to human and planetary well being.
Featured in the profit 100, and winner of the award in the province of Quebec, he has always been a humble visionary, able to see opportunities years before they happen, always happy and grateful to share, collaborate and help his surroundings. 

His involvement in both the Plant-Based Food and Healthcare industries and the co-founding Healthcentric A.I is showing his flair for future successful ventures.

Alnoor is on a mission to improve the world via food, education and technology while helping humans and companies, NGO to evolve themselves into their best-self, and never refuse to help someone on the same mission. 

He is involved in NGO and has worked as a volunteer all around the globe, to be helping future entrepreneurs to jump and create their dreams. He is always saying that he loves to be creating a space for people to reinvent themselves into the entrepreneur they are meant to become.

Bio:
Roland Marconi is a producer, digital film-maker, editor and DP/cameraman as well as a musician and composer based in the New York area. He is the Producer/Director of Media Dream Productions based in Brooklyn, NY. 
He has shot and edited daily content for CBSNews.com as well as designed and maintained the CBSNews.com production studio, directed, and edited more than 20 public health and investigative reporting video documentaries for Gary Null Productions for which he has helped to win numerous national and regional video awards.
Roland has also done freelance work for such diverse media entities such as Yahoo Finance, TheStreet, Global Vision Group, INN World Report, World Peace Productions, New Jersey Dance Theatre Ensemble, We Are The World, and The New York Society for Ethical Culture producing documentaries, news, corporate, promotional, music and performing arts videos.
In addition to editing video for Global Vision Group’s “The Amazon Rainforest”, Gary Null Productions’ award winning “Gulf War Syndrome: A Deadly Legacy” and “Deconstructing the Myth of AIDS” he also composed and produced the musical soundtracks. 
He has composed, performed and produced music and video art for several bands and modern dance pieces including Millennium Project’s “Captured” and Turano Dance Company’s productions of “Carmen”, “Carmen in the Underworld” and “Luminea”.

Bio:
Beatrice Briggs, Founder and Director, IIFAC. IAF Certified™ Professional Facilitator;  Member International Association of Facilitators

I work with leaders to identify the weak spots in their meeting processes. Together we create the conditions that make their meetings worth the time, talent and money invested in them. 

I have had the honor of working in over 30 countries with an impressive array of change-oriented organizations, including UNICEF, World Wildlife Fund, Inter-American Development Bank, and the International Center for Development Research, as well as many local initiatives. These experiences have confirmed that boring, unproductive meetings are universal phenomena. I am so grateful to be able to use my skills as a professional facilitator to help alleviate the suffering caused by bad meetings wherever they occur. 

A native of the United States, I have made Mexico my home since 1998. Since then I have become fluent in Spanish, developed a taste for salsa picante, mole and tequila and made many, amazing friends. To maintain my US connections, I do the New York Times crossword puzzle and visit family and friends in "el norte" as often as possible.

I would love to talk to you about your meeting challenges and how to transform them into a success story that you can be proud of. Email me at bbriggs@iifac.org to schedule a conversation - in English or Spanish!

Bio:
Anamarija Frankic is the Founding Director of Green Harbors Project & Biomimicry LivingLabs. 

My love and passion is to work with nature, by learning, teaching and doing biomimicry while addressing coastal issues and adapting to changes locally and globally. Natural coastal systems and local keystone species like oysters (my favorite) and habitats such as shellfish beds, salt marshes and eel grasses work together in sharing water, energy and food nexus, providing us with ecological services that stabilize our coasts, sediments, filter water of nutrients and pollutants, supporting conditions conducive to life. Observing and learning from coastal systems leads naturally into a discussion how to apply this wisdom in our, human built environment (Frankic et al. 2011). The most significant impediment to sustaining our coastal natural and human built systems is not a lack of technical knowledge but the lack of collaboration and communication in understanding the whole systems-level intricacies that true conservation, restoration and resilience require. Nature is resilient and we are nature, so let's just remember how to do it.
Name: Anamaria Frankic
