Bio:
Jan Hein van der Hoeven is Treasurer of the Board of Directors of Ecosystem Restoration Camps. 

Jan Hein van der Hoeven is from Langbroek and is the father of 3 little sons and the husband of a wonderful wife. He grew up on the farm of his parents with 3 more brothers and loved it there.

He has a double master’s degree in Social and Organisational Psychology and worked for different NGO’s (Bottletop Unite, EnAccion) and different businesses (Dell, Versatel, Ardeco, RobinGood) before deciding to become a mediator. After that he got another master’s degree in Australia (Business). When he came back to the Netherlands, he launched an IT start up. He ran the business for 8 years and helped to grow it to a multimillion business with 12 FTE.

This past year he also had the opportunity to run his family farm and although he still has to move there he started to learn about new ways of running an estate. (The old model was build houses so you could afford nature). He learned more about how to become self-sustainable and about permaculture.

He is not an activist but loves the positive attitude of permaculture. He loves to be Self Reliant, to think Positive and to Leave People and Planet better behind then how you found them. He feels most at home translating a vision to possible business partners / donors and/or implementing growth strategies. He is a dreamer with a can do mentality.. He’s writing a children’s novel now which ultimately, besides a little self-sustaining farm is his life’s goal. But help saving the wold from self-destruction takes a good second place![

Specialties: Business development, concept development, stakeholder management, Harvard trained negotiator, lumberjack, social permaculture, investor.
Name: Jan Hein

Bio:
Ron Whitehurst, specialist in biological pest control and restoration of agro-ecosystems, consults for farmers, gardeners, consultants and practitioners. He facilitates learning about insect pests and solutions in field, greenhouse, landscape, garden and animal rearing situations. His lively discussions about insect lifecycles and predator-prey relationships make the principles of biocontrol easy to understand for both lay and technical audiences. He is a member of the California Sustainable Pest Management Work Group, working with 25 stakeholders to develop a pathway to a future with less use of toxic pesticides.

 Ron is a California licensed Pest Control Advisor and co-owner of Rincon-Vitova Insectaries, Inc. that produces and markets supplies for biological pest control and agroecology. With a BA in biology from Indiana University, Ron early on worked as an organic garden writer, and helped organize an organic grower association. He has been communicating about organic methods of farming and gardening for over 40 years. Since 1997 he has guided people through the steps of creating and biologically managing ecosystems to grow healthy plants to minimize and control pests, using insect habitat, cultural methods, beneficial insects, and soft pesticides when needed. He has led projects for the Dietrick Institute for Applied Insect Ecology, co-located with Rincon-Vitova. An avid gardener, he loves making compost, building soil, and creating bio-intensive food producing landscapes. 

Ron’s mentor is Everett (Deke) Dietrick, commercial biocontrol pioneer, who worked alongside the academic lights of biocontrol in the 1960’s and 70’s, Robert Van den Bosch, Paul De Bach and others. Like Deke, Ron evaluates products and strategies that fit into a biocontrol program and are acceptable for organic production. He works with his wife Jan Dietrick (Deke’s daughter), and is the proud grandfather of a twenty one year old. 

Past presentations: Ecological Farming and Texas Organic Producers Conferences, ACRES USA, Carolina Farm Stewardship Conference, So Cal Entomology Club, Association of Applied IPM Ecologists (AAIE), Pesticide Applicators Professional Association (PAPA), Ojai Horticulture Society, Ventura County and San Fernando Valley Rose Societies, workshops of the Santa Barbara Green Gardener Program, Bio-Cat Microbials, Cockroach, New Pests of Avocados and G. S. Long Organic Workshops, and workshops on Weeds as Soil Indicators and Edible Weeds.
Name: Ron Whitehurst

Bio: Ron is a founder and board member of Borderlands Restoration, L3C and Regents Professor Emeritus in the Eugene P. Odum School of Ecology at the University of Georgia. His former positions include President of the Ecological Society of America, Director of the National Biological Service, Science Advisor to the Secretary of Interior, and Director of the Institute of Ecology. Pulliam has also served on numerous boards and commissions, as an advisor to several major philanthropic foundations, and as chairman of the board of NatureServe. Pulliam has published over 150 scientific articles and books on topics including niche theory, foraging and flocking behavior, source sink dynamics, protection of endangered species, and the effects of climate and land use on plant and animal abundance and distribution. Among many awards received by Pulliam are the Distinguished Service Award from the Ecological Society of America and the Distinguished Landscape Ecologist Award from the International Association for Landscape Ecology.

Bio:
Working on behalf of Nature Bringing Back The Fish 

After a long time working to replenish and restore ocean pastures I've finally successfully done this in the largest such project. In 2012 we restored an ocean pasture in the NE Pacific, Gulf of Alaska, some tens of thousands of square kilometers in size. Independent reports in the scientific literature confirmed that our ocean pasture was returned to a state of productivity equal to the best on record or better.

The really good news arrived last fall in the form of 226 million salmon swimming into the nets of fishermen in Alaska's largest catch of salmon in all of history. The projections were for a good catch of 50 million fish. These northern Pink salmon were a primary target of our ocean pasture restoration along with some other populations, including the Fraser Sockeye, which are now projected to be swimming home in numbers exceeding last year's return of 2 million fish. Indeed 72 million of the bright red sockeye are predicted, the largest prediction in all of history. 

Here's a link to a YouTube Video of a Press Conference on the project by the Haida Village Council. https://shorturl.at/akR35

IT JUST WORKS! My blog at russgeorge.net tells the tale in more detail

On the personal biographical side, I started my serial eco-restortion business founding with a tree planting business in the early seventies. Over scores of years with scores of people working, this resulted in 'gazillions' of trees now growing, making home and health for all of nature.

On many occasions, I have been called upon to give expert testimony to the US House and Senate, the Pentagon Joint Chiefs, World Bank, major scientific and medical societies, and nations around the world
Name: Russ George

Bio: Vance was asked by Ian Player in 1983 to return to the US and resurrect the International Wilderness Leadership Foundation. In 1984, he therefore restructured and established the WILD Foundation and became President and board member, in which capacity he served through 2022. An innovative leader known for bridging the interests of people and nature, he has lived extensively overseas, worked in over 80 countries, and helped to establish many non-profit organizations. An acknowledged expert in international nature conservation and wilderness protection, including strong friendships and working partnerships with traditional and indigenous community leaders, he continues to serve on the boards of numerous organizations such as the Cheetah Conservation Fund, Friends of Peace Parks, EarthToday/Union of Nature, International Conservation Caucus Foundation, and others. He is also a co-founder and President Emeritus of Wilderness Foundation Global (based in South Africa), and the Founder/Co-chair of the Wilderness Specialist Group (part of the World Commission on Protected Areas, within the International Union for the Conservation of Nature). He is the prolific author/editor of many publications in numerous countries. A native of the U.S. Piedmont region, he graduated magna cum laude from West Virginia University. For more information about Vance, please visit his wikipedia page or check out this 2021 interview with our colleagues at great.com.

Bio:
John is a seasoned leader, a Senior Director at CIFOR-ICRAF and Co-Founder and Senior Strategic Adviser of the Global Landscapes Forum (GLF), the world’s largest and fastest-growing community for sustainable landscapes, founded by CIFOR, the World Bank, and UNEP. Over the past decade, he has directed and expanded GLF to engage a global audience of more than one billion people annually across 175 countries, with 75% of the audience in the Global South. GLF has launched—and is actively expanding—over 90 community-led development projects, with an ambitious target of reaching 500 projects by 2028. Under John's leadership, GLF has secured more than €60 million in funding and is supported by a growing and talented team of 70 staff and consultants, along with 35 Charter Members, including the world's leading development organizations.

Before joining GLF, John served as Communications Director at the Center for International Forestry Research, where he led the design and execution of CIFOR’s communication strategy, achieving double- and triple-digit growth across platforms for over ten years. He served as a strategic advisor to four Director-Generals, leading a team whose innovative efforts redefined CIFOR’s global impact and elevated forests to a prominent position on the political agenda.

A former TIME Hong Kong Bureau Chief, John began his career in journalism, spending 12 years as a radio, broadcast, and print correspondent across Asia. With a rich background in journalism, forestry, and development communication, he has received multiple awards for his reporting and public service. After TIME John spent three years as a Senior Vice President at PCCW, a global technology conglomerate in Hong Kong (formerly Hong Kong Telecom)

John is passionate about advancing a global agenda on landscapes, climate change, biodiversity, and sustainable development. He thrives on fostering impactful collaborations and driving innovative solutions to create a more just, equitable and sustainable planet.
Comments: John is a filmmaker who a few years back brought out Symbiotic Earth, a wonderful film about Lynn Margulis and the implications of her work https://hummingbirdfilms.com/symbioticearth/. John’s forthcoming film, Regenerating Life https://hummingbirdfilms.com/regenerating-life/, encompasses all the wonderful soil, water cycle and overall eco-restoration solutions that have gotten us so inspired. He lives in the Hudson Valley, not too far from Judy S.

Bio:
Chief Culture and Business Development Officer. ThePivot.Earth. Stewarding regenerative living soil projects that engage communities to create thriving food systems. For all. No exceptions. Living Soil. Mutuality. Thriving Community. 
Conscious leadership and a deep dive into the root causes of alarming chronic inflammation brings the vitality of our soil and communities into the light of transformation. The astonishing healing power of linking diverse living soil ecosystems and thriving individual and community health through systems of mutual development and growth is the work we do. 

Through trust and connection, inspired stakeholders engage in courageous conversations to identify the systems, cultural shifts and “missing pieces” that solve for a truly regenerative and resilient local community based on living soil, mutuality and thriving community. Through conscious leadership principles and globally proven frameworks and constructs, we co-create and collaborate models that revolutionize land, community and what it means to live in reciprocity on the Earth.Living Soil. Bio:
It is our pleasure at Reap Goodness to restore Earth through training development on formation of trios of cooperative groups to 1) harvest rainwater on land and off roofs, 2) planand plant food forests, and 3) plant ecosystem restoration plants and their support plants. This will enjoin communities and divide the work, with many hands making light work. 

This model is being developed for upper primary grades worldwide through training packages for teachers and sutdents to do this work while providing healthy permaculture foods right outside the school doors. Upon expertise by students, they will be able to train adults in communities within the school districts. This model will restore Earth's ecosystems while providing nutritious foods for growing bodies and minds worldwide. 

Reap Goodness is currently testing this model in two locations in the Arizona desert, one in an urban area, another in open country on a slope. So if you want to show Reap Goodness on the map, please do. Later we are going global through embassies to get the training packages into the countries' schools in upper primary grades. 

We look forward to convening with you and others like us!

Bio:
Tony Rinaudo served as an agriculturalist and missionary with ‘Serving in Mission’ in Niger Republic from 1981 to 1999. There, he oversaw long-term rural development and periodic, large-scale relief programs. Through these, he contributed to a transformation in how Nigeriens farm, and the reforesting of over six million hectares of land, which still inspires re-greening movements globally. For his 18 years of service to humanity and the environment, the government of Niger awarded him its highest honour for an expatriate “The Order of Agriculture with Merit” (Merite Agricole du Niger). 

Since joining World Vision Australia in 1999, Tony initiated and/or oversaw important land regeneration projects, worldwide. Serving now as Principal Climate Action Advisor, he promotes forestry and agro-forestry initiatives globally within the World Vision partnership, and beyond. 

He is widely recognized for his influential contribution to heightened international awareness of the impact, efficacy, and uptake of simple, low-cost, scalable methods of reforestation known as FMNR (Farmer-Managed Natural Regeneration). Among major awards Tony and FMNR have recently received are the 2018 Right Livelihood Award “for demonstrating on a large scale how drylands can be greened at minimal cost, improving the livelihoods of millions of people”, and the World Future Council Agroecology Award. In 2019, Tony was appointed as a Member (AM) of the Order of Australia (General Division)."People who had lost hope, who saw themselves as failures and had no way out of the downward spiral of poverty and despair, now have hope through restoring their land and seeing life breathed back into the landscape. Being able to provide for their families, people's sense of self-worth, pride, and dignity have been restored. They feel liberated – this simple approach, FMNR – a solution literally at their feet, enables and empowers them to create the future they want for themselves and their children!" My official biography: Tony Rinaudo served as an agriculturalist and missionary with ‘Serving in Mission’ in Niger Republic from 1981 to 1999. There, he oversaw long-term rural development and periodic, large-scale relief programs. Through these, he contributed to a transformation in how Nigeriens farm, and the reforesting of over six million hectares of land, which still inspires re-greening movements globally. Bio:
I am passionate about environmental restoration and connecting science with the community. Ecology is my base, and I have extensive project management related to environmental issues, specifically in ecology, sustainability and environmental restoration. I work closely with State and Federal government agencies, NGOs, schools and community stakeholders. 

I developed and lead a Miyawaki forest research and outreach program. The research is investigating use of Miyawaki (or pocket) forests for urban greening, increasing urban biodiversity and improving urban liveability in the Australian context. The outreach program brings pocket forests into schools via a dedicated STEM program that empowers students, enabling them to take tangible environmental action, whiles also providing them with practical and theoretical STEM learnings.

Bio:
Zoology graduate from Cardiff University with a strong career background in business development. Lucky enough to say im combining my skill set and passion for conserving and restoring our earths ecosystems. 

"Restor was Born out of the Crowther Lab at ETH Zurich and powered by Google. At Restor, our mission is to support and accelerate the restoration of earth's ecosystems for biodiversity, climate and people. We are doing this by bringing every actor involved in nature restoration on one single free digital platform in order to: enable effective and responsible restoration, to catalyze investment into nature restoration projects, and ultimately inspire a global restoration movement."

Bio:
Veteran planetary & ecosystems health & policy strategist, biodiversity/ global change scientist, filmmaker. Campaign Advisor, Global Evergreening Alliance; Affiliate Prof, Univ Washington; Associate, Univ Cape Town.

I'm a global change and climate scientist, systems and policy analyst, conservation biologist, environmental and societal futurist, sustainability risk and resilience strategist, climate bioadaptation science-policy analyst, writer, editor, mentor, professor and film co-producer - interested in finding collaborative spatial planning and human behavior solutions to potentially high-conflict wicked problems. I'm an inveterate team-builder to accelerate and deepen science-policy impact. Outgoing CEO of the Stable Planet Alliance, a coalition of like-minded scientific, technical, health, education, women's empowerment and grassroots organizations collaborating to bend the needle on our devastating human numbers, appetites, and mindsets, and building the Global Restoration Collaborative, a bold network of networks to accelerate, align, upskill and upscale ecosystem restoration, climate restoration, and the collaborative leadership and intergenerational mentorship of women, youth and indigenous cultural bridges. Thirty-six years of deep experience, founding and leading climate change and biodiversity programs, teaching and founding and leading organizations across southern and eastern Africa and North America. In 2017 I returned to the USA to work on early warning systems, green economic recovery, climate migration and displacement, managed coastal retreat planning, and triple-whammy episodic events. Am also Affiliate Full Professor at the University of Washington (Center for Environmental Politics and School of Interdisciplinary Arts & Sciences), and Research Associate at the University of Cape Town (African Climate and Development Initiative and the Fitzpatrick Institute of African Ornithology). Contact me at phoebe.barnard@stableplanetalliance.org.

When not working, I climb mountains and volcanoes, run in the forests, develop a community victory garden, and go adventuring with my groovy husband, filmmaker John Bowey, our puppies and family when they are visiting.
Name: Phoebe Barnard
updates: Posting: not allowed  ||  Email Pref: not allowed

Bio:
About
Natalie Topa is a global expert in regenerative design and resilience, with 20 years of experience restoring landscapes and designing agroecosystems to support climate adaptation, food security, water security, soil health, and seed sovereignty. Trained as an urban and regional planner, she began her international work in 2005 in South Sudan, where she witnessed ecological collapse—nutrient loss, hydrological breakdown, and degraded soils—as a root driver of humanitarian crises. This realization shaped her life’s mission: to help communities heal the natural systems that sustain them.

Natalie trains farmers, pastoralists, and communities to implement practical, land-based solutions—such as passive water harvesting, large-scale half-moons, bioswales, earthen dams, and integrated stoneworks—to rehydrate soils, slow erosion, restore biodiversity, and buffer against drought and flood. Her designs span homesteads, farms, infrastructure, and full watershed systems, grounded in circular systems thinking and deep ecological ethics.
Name: Natalie Topa

Bio:
Ecological Economist.  Fred Jennings is from Ipswich, Massachusetts, USA, where he has spent most of his life. He is an ecological economist with a B.A. from Harvard and a Ph.D. from Stanford, both in economics. Fred is also an avid conservationist and fly fisherman. He enjoys the outdoors, and has written about natural processes and about economic theory. He has 40 years of teaching and research experience, first in academics and then in economic litigation. He also enjoys his seasonal practice as a saltwater fly fishing guide in Ipswich, MA. Fred joined Biodiversity for a Livable Climate in 2016.

Bio:
As Creative Director at Urban Reef and tutor at Delft University of Technology, I blend my interest in regenerative future landscapes with design and education. With a PhD in Strategic Design and practice experience in architecture, I am driven by a commitment to integrate ecological dynamics into urban spaces, while exploring advanced technologies, new media and bio-based materials. 

As Associated Researcher at the Creative School at Toronto Metropolitan University, I am involved in research and network development on regenerative design, focusing on business frameworks for design practices.

Urban Reef’s team focuses on conceptualising, designing and realising bio-inclusive environments with 3D-printed samples. My role involves conceptual design, strategic planning, stakeholder engagement, and guiding pilot projects from ideation to execution and reflection. 

I am always looking to connect with like-minded professionals, academics, students, and organisations passionate about creating open ended, thriving urban environments. Let's connect and explore how we can collaborate for realising green and healthy futures!

Bio: Executive Director of the Ecosystem Restoration Camps Foundation. ​Inextricably linked to our current natural systems, humanity needs to develop it's society and economy sustainably. Not one actor can do this alone. Where business holds many of the tools needed (people, finance, innovation) it requires collaboration with science (ideas, data), government (regulatory and convening power, legitimacy) and NGOs (vision, and needed perspectives). I am strongly convinced that we can create economies of abundance and inclusion through using regenerative agricultural techniques, biomimicry and the realisation of a circular economy. I have worked on governance models, reporting and transparency initiatives, natural capital valuation, collaborative models, marketing of ideas, management, policy development within NGOs, multi-stakeholder initiatives and finance. Currently, I am an independent consultant that can help organisations understand and collaborate with its stakeholders, develop sustainability strategies and policies, and find responses to sustainability issues. And I am passionate about ecosystem restoration, to which I devote my energy as executive director of the Ecosystem Restoration Camps Foundation.​

Bio:
Didi Pershouse is changing the dialogue wherever she goes by showing the nestedness of soil health, human health, the biological workforce, and the climate. She is the author of "The Ecology of Care: Medicine, Agriculture, Money, and the Quiet Power of Human and Microbial Communities" and a contributing author for "Health in the Anthropocene." 

As the founder of the Center for Sustainable Medicine, she developed a practice and theoretical framework for systems-based ecological medicine—to restore health to people as well as the environmental and social systems around them. After 22 years of clinical work with patients, Pershouse now travels widely in North America and Europe as a speaker, teacher, and consultant.

Pershouse is a skilled facilitator, who brings conservatives and liberals together into effective working groups with common goals: improving soil health, public health, food and water security, and regional resilience through simple changes in land management. Both online and in-person, her participatory workshops engage farmers and ranchers, policy makers, investors, and scientists in living-systems thinking and deep listening, to allow for emergent strategies. She was one of five speakers at the United Nations-FAO World Soil Day in 2017.
​
In 2018, she founded the Land and Leadership Initiative, and the "Can we Rehydrate California?" Initiative. She is currently a Planning Commissioner for her town, a Supervisor at the White River Natural Resources Conservation District, and is on the board of directors of Regenerate Earth, the Soil Carbon Coalition and the Vermont Healthy Soils Coalition. She led a successful effort to conserve the Zebedee Headwaters Wetlands while serving as a Vermont Conservation Commissioner, and while serving on the Vermont State appointed Payment For Ecosystem Services and Soil Health Working Group she helped to shift the outcome away from Wall Street and toward a more localized approach.

She is currently working on projects with the UN-FAO Farmer Field School program; and the Andhra Pradesh Community Managed Natural Farming initiative in India (involving over 1 million farmers). 

In all of these projects, her goal is to reorient people away from the "sterile" way we have approached global challenges for the last century—killing off whatever we don't want—and move people instead toward a ‘fertile’ collaboration with the systems around them.
Name: Didi Pershouse

Bio:
Founder & CEO, Open Future Coalition | Global impact through local exchange

Kaitlin Archambault is a systems architect, designer, creative director, & communications strategist with over a decade of experience growing and leading creative and product teams. She started her career in public media, branding and growing the reach and funding of NPR and PBS programs as a part of The Futuro Media Group. In 2013, she went on to found Brooklyn-based creative studio Incendiary Designs, which has built and grown nonprofit and social good brands on 5 continents. Kaitlin has worked to advance education policy and grown thought leadership programs for placement in outlets like the New York Times, the Washington Post, and The Hill. 

With experiences that range from designing institutional-grade financial services platforms to leading global organizations through complex rebrands, Kaitlin recognizes that a truly design-driven approach takes into account issues of governance, compliance, and ethics. These days, she spends much of her time at the intersection between user experience, human behavior, and economics to ensure that emerging technologies—like blockchain and artificial intelligence—are thoughtfully constructed for the greater good. 

In 2021, she founded Open Future Coalition, a social enterprise committed to helping the global impact ecosystem strengthen its collaborative capacity by empowering the transparent exchange of capital, skills, and knowledge. They recently launched Open Impact, a network where impact organizations, donors, & community members can come together to match the right organizations with the right resources to maximize impact. 

Kaitlin’s background is in public art and grassroots movement building: she was part of the initial press push and benefit campaign around the imprisonment of Russian punk band Pussy Riot, and has taught art therapy at the women’s jail on Riker’s Island.

Interests:
• Applying systems thinking & economics to build incentive-aligned teams, products, & brands 
• Solving tough problems—like complex alignment processes with a lot of stakeholders, balancing community-stewarded funding models with institutional-grade risk & compliance, & governance for distributed orgs 
• Working at the intersection of politics, media, & education 
• Regenerative economic models & microfinance 
• Lean & scalable regulation & governance of emerging tech 
• Using emerging tech to empower & educate young people & citizen scientists
Name: Kaitlin Archambault

Bio: Monifa Maat, known affectionately by her clients as The Healthy Motivator is a Nationally Certified Personal Trainer, home fitness and nutrition advocate, and Founder of Healthy Roots Fitness & Nutrition Camp (HRFNC), based at the historic Mother AME Zion Church in Harlem, New York. Ms. Maat’s work is dedicated to reducing the incidence of chronic lifestyle diseases such as obesity, diabetes and heart disease in predominantly African American and Latino urban communities hardest hit by the epidemic. Bio:
CEO @ Savimbo. MD-technologist, pacifist, and delinquent savant.
Savimbo  Stanford University School of Medicine

I'm a pacifist. My work is focused on integration during an era of extreme technological and environmental change. As an MD-technologist and serial entrepreneur, I apply high-tech from hard-science in critical sectors. I lead a team of 300+ delinquent savants who specialize in solving hard scientific and social problems using emerging technologies. Our latest project is Savimbo which sells fair-trade climate credits direct from smallfarmers and Indigenous groups in tropical forests. 

Prior work includes biodiversity credits, carbon sequestration, Web3 (DeFi, crypto, smart-contracts, GameFi, SocialFi, and digital ledgers), wearables, film production, newspace, behavior design, civ-tech and smart cities, AI and ML, cybersecurity, near-infrared spectroscopy, fMRI, stem cells and tissue-engineering, 3D printing, VR, specialist networks, nanotech, voice-recognition software, microbiome, web/app product design, business and startup strategy, social enterprise, popular-science writing, scientific PR and niche marketing. In global health, I develop high-tech for low-resource environments.

We use emerging technologies to promote population health. We are apolitical and industry-agnostic to this aim and passionate about reducing barriers to innovation at the intersection of research, technology, and science.

We recruit and train high-IQ individuals with non-traditional backgrounds working with the military, law, medicine, computer science, business developers, finance, creatives, indigenous peoples, and academics around the world. 

To quote Karen Kilroy "I can't help but wonder how much further technology could go if we solved things for people who had the biggest problems first — and then made games."
Name: Drea Burbank

Bio:
Bernd Walter Mueller is a permaculture and water specialist
and head of Tamera's ecology project.

Born in Cologne, Germany, he is a Nature researcher, specialist in the construction of Water Retention Landscapes, permaculturist, and a dowser.

Since 2007, he has been a co-worker of the Peace Research Centre Tamera in Portugal, in close coopeation with Sepp Holzer.
Today Bernd Mueller is director of the Ecology Department of Tamera and teacher of the Global Campus, an international training centre for peace workers.

In 1986 he abandoned his engineering studies in the traditional university system because he did not find the answers he sought.
He started his own business, ran a health food store, worked in landscape gardening and later in tree care.
In 1989 he emigrated to Spain and managed an organic farm in the Sierra Nevada. There he found the necessary calmness to study natural processes through intense observation.
He discovered a new, more subtle possibility of cooperation between man and nature.

Today he transfers the insights from this process of self-education into the practical development of ecological models for landscape healing and the restoration of the Earth.

The Water Retention Landscape is a model for natural decentralized water management, restoration of damaged ecosystems and disaster prevention.

Bio:
Evgenia Emets is an international artist and poet and the Founder of the Eternal Forest Global project. She was born in Poltava, Ukraine, USSR, in 1979, has lived in Moscow, Russia and London, UK and has been living in Portugal since 2017. She graduated with an MA Fine Art, at Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design, London in 2008. 

Evgenia works with forest ecology and community creating visual art, films, artist’s books, forest trails and experiences and large-scale ecological artworks in the form of forest sanctuaries. 
Eternal Forest (launched 2018 in Portugal), an ongoing multidisciplinary project, marks an integration of ecological thinking into her art. Eternal Forest is creating a network of 1,000 forest sanctuaries to be protected for 1,000 years through art and community. 

Eternal Forest has been presented in Portugal, Spain, Mexico, the US and the UK: Bienal de Coruche in 2019 and CI.CLO / Bienal Fotografia do Porto, Roots & Seeds, Quo Artis, Barcelona in 2021, Pela Terra, an encounter for earth and community in Idanha-a-Velha, Portugal in 2023 and at Municipal Gallery of Porto, Crystal Palace Gardens in 2024.

Recent solo shows: 2024 Rewilding Time, Hall of Biodiversity – Ciência Viva Center, Porto, 2023, Forest Time, Estufa Fria and Monsanto Forest Park in Lisbon, 2022, National Museum of Natural History and Science and Botanical Garden of Lisbon.

Awards: 2022/2023/2024 Municipality of City of Lisbon Grant; 2020 CiClo Sustentar, Portugal; 2019 Arts Council, KIMA: Noise film and installation, Analema Group, Tate Exchange/Tate Modern, UK; 2018 CineEco Seia, Regional Award for Eternal Forest film, Portugal; 2016 Arts Council, KIMA, Analema Group, Roundhouse, UK; 2014 Arts Council, KIMA, Analema Group, Union Chapel, UK

Evgenia’s visual works and artists’ books are in museums (Stella Art Foundation and MOMA, Russia), libraries (National Poetry Library, London, British Library and Gulbenkian Art Library) and private collections in the UK, Europe, Japan and Russia.
Name: Evgenia Emets

Bio: Betsy Damon is an internationally recognized artist whose work with water, site-specific sculptures, and performance has received widespread acclaim and publication. Since 1985, Betsy has focused on water and ecological issues. She created the Living Water Garden in Sichuan, China, a six-acre urban park that has become an icon of natural water-cleaning systems. Her current projects include ReSources: Saving Living Systems, a project to document living Tibetan water culture in the Eastern Himalayas, and Living Waters of Larimer: A Fresh Infrastructure, a project for community action and sustainable water design in Pittsburgh, PA. Betsy is the founder of the nonprofit Keepers of the Waters, through which she promotes environmental education, ecological planning, community projects and advocacy worldwide.
Name: Betsy Damon

Biography
Thomas Goreau promotes coral reef protection by documenting stresses to reef ecosystems, identifying the causes of these stresses and proposing strategies to restore these species-rich and highly sensitive ecosystems. He launched the Global Coral Reef Alliance (GCRA) in 1993 as a coalition of action-oriented scientists, divers, environmentalists and other individuals and organizations who are concerned about coral reefs. GCRA focuses on issues related to global climate change, diseases, pollution, integrated coastal zone and watershed management, rapid assessment of reef health and restoration of coral reefs.

Bio:
Founder & CEO - The Climate PI (Foundation for Planetary Intelligence)

On a dedicated research mission to uncover data and insights to inform the critical intersections of human wellness, climate, sustainability, ESG, biodiversity, socio-economics, geopolitics and technology. 

We don't have a waste, people, climate and sustainability problem - we have a systems design problem. Understanding how and where to apply all of the solutions and intelligence we have to create a circular and regenerative system is the mission. Decision Intelligence (DI), generative AI, human and planetary intelligence in data are the tools we use to power the climate risk predictor and solutions recommender that is The PI. https://youtu.be/vNGSkRo1_D0

Many of the solutions to solve climate and create our sustainable future already exist. What we're missing is a roadmap to deploy & scale them. The Foundation for Planetary Intelligence is building an AI powered solution recommender to help us understand which solutions need to go where, in which combination - with impact projection.

Our mission is to use decision intelligence to recommend best-fit solutions by context (business or government) to Map the Path to A Sustainable Future for People and Planet.


Our vision: https://youtu.be/vNGSkRo1_D0
Name: Jennie-Marie Larsen

Bio:
Prof. Chandrashekhar M. Biradar (CM Biradar) is an earth system scientist, founder, green growth leader, and pioneer in biodiversity and agroecosystem restoration with 30+ years of global experience. His work integrates biodiversity conservation, regenerative agroecosystems, dryland restoration, agroforestry, and climate resilience. With expertise in agriculture, forestry, AI, big data, and geospatial technologies, he has led scientific and policy initiatives at CGIAR centers, U.S. universities, and international organizations. His focus includes ecosystem restoration, soil health, springshed revival, functional food systems, and climate-smart agroecology.

A champion of One Health, Pancha Maha Bhutas, and Mission LiFE, he has spearheaded Green Growth in Drylands, Desert Farming, Food Forests, Heritage Food Systems, and promoting agroforestry, land restoration, and community-driven conservation. As a scientific advisor and board member on numbers of organizations, he advocates for regenerative landscapes, functional production, biodiversity credits, springsheds and green economic growth to support resilient livelihoods and Net Zero transition.
Name: Chandrashekhar Biradar
Other Links: ICARDIA | Logo | CGIAR | Logo | GeoAgro | Logo | GeoAroPro | ePage

Bio: Mick Lorusso is a cross-disciplinary artist who interweaves musings on molecules, cells, societies, and environments. He creates images, cabinets of curiosity and interactions to address questions about energy, water, climate, and health. He has been a resident artist at interdisciplinary art programs, including PLAND / ISEA 2012: Machine Wilderness (Taos, NM, USA), the 2016 Rauschenberg Rising Waters Confab (Captiva, FL, USA), and Matza Aletsch 2017 in the Swiss Alps. At a residency in Schöppingen, Germany, Lorusso harnessed electricity-producing bacteria to illuminate a sculptural village, Microbial Schöppingen, which received a hybrid art honorary mention at Ars Electronica 2013. With early training in microbiology and education in art at Colorado College (BA) and San Francisco Art Institute (MFA), he is a research fellow at the UCLA Art|Sci Center and an instructor for the UCLA Sci|Art Nanolab Summer Institute. He is a graduate of the Waag Biohack Academy, and is a member of the Mexican interdisciplinary cooperative XOCIARTEK. Lorusso is a certified Kundalini Yoga Instructor, teaching classes that integrate visual art, science, and yoga.

Bio:
Joe Brewer is the founder of Earth Regenerators, co-founder of the Design School for Regenerating Earth, co-founder of Fundación Barichara Regenerativa, and a steward for Bioregional Earth.

He is a regenerative designer who works on large-scale system change by bringing deep knowledge and experience from complexity, cultural evolution, the cognitive sciences, and Earth Systems. Throughout the last five years, Joe has helped catalyze a bioregional regeneration effort in the Northern Andes of Colombia. This includes a focus on ecosystem restoration, regenerative education, alternative approaches to flow funding and regenerative finance, and collaboration at landscape scales.

You can learn more about his work by reading his book “The Design Pathway for Regenerating Earth” or by checking out the Design School for Regenerating Earth.

Bio: ​Founder at SoilWatch; Strategy & Partnerships for Climate Action; Emergency Specialist​. Climate tech founder and sustainable agriculture and nature-based solutions nerd with humanitarian emergencies and public policy experience thrown in.  At SoilWatch, we're on a mission to help achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by enabling landscape regeneration where it is needed most; on the frontlines of the climate emergency.  With nature-based solutions, gigatonnes of CO2 can be removed from the atmosphere as soils are restored. And thanks to our deep tech solution combining open satellite data and peer-reviewed research, it can be done in a transparent and verifiable way.  Not in a decade. Not in five years. But now.  Over the years I've also worked on emergency humanitarian interventions, climate change, conflict, human rights and sustainable development, as well as spending time explaining digital targeting and advocating data protection. As a consultancy Director and coordinator, I've enabled impact focused teams to achieve their goals at national, European and international level.  I am also very happy to connect with others working on conservation, carbon dioxide removal, sustainable land management, ESG, SDGs, conflict mitigation, famine prevention and relief, natural disasters, remote sensing, machine learning. The issues we work on are too great for any one organisation, so let's talk.

Bio:
I bring knowledge to communities to catalyze successful, local actions to address climate/sustainability problems. 

I am founder of Common Action, an innovation network facilitating climate and sustainability action through the development of community and knowledge graph technology. We are working to build public, collective knowledge graphs enabling decentralized reporting of environmental, social, and economic conditions related to sustainability, as well as connections between companies, non-profits, academics, entrepreneurs, government, citizens, and more. Both of these efforts are designed to produce a coherent, collective force across society for responding to urgent global priorities. 

Previously I served as Head of Community and Director of Conference Operations at The Knowledge Graph Conference. To support the development of the global semantic community, I launched the KGC public Slack and a number of events, including the popular KGC Book Club series and Knowledge Espresso video podcast. Over a year, the KGC Slack grew to over 2,000 members. 

My background in sustainability is specifically focused on climate change, with career experience in both renewable energy and sustainable agriculture. I am particularly focused on designing change with growth, narrative, community, and action.

Bio:
Marie Noëlle is the co-founder and CEO of WeForest, a non-profit organization dedicated to tackling some of today’s most pressing challenges: global warming, water scarcity, biodiversity loss, and poverty. Leading a team of 90 professionals—primarily based in Africa—she has overseen the restoration of more than 80,000 hectares (an area larger than Singapore) with over  106 million trees, transforming the lives of over half a million people, creating habitats for endangered species, and positively impacting adjacent landscapes 40 times larger (an area the size of Belgium).
WeForest is now at a pivotal point for scaling up: with the right level of funding, it could more than double what has been achieved in the past 15 years, demonstrating that bold, collective action truly works.
Her background is unconventional: after 19 years in senior positions at leading French and U.S. corporations, she decided to align her career with her life’s purpose and co-founded WeForest in 2009. Drawing on her business experience, an MBA, and a Master’s in Environmental Sciences, she helped shape WeForest into the respected reforestation NGO it is today.
She also collaborates with global coalitions such as Al Gore’s Climate Reality Corps and the WEF 1t.org advisory council, participates in peer groups to broaden the collective impact. Always open to new collaborations, Marie Noëlle welcomes opportunities to connect with entrepreneurs and changemakers, as no one can do this alone.

Bio: Anastassia Makarieva graduated from Leningrad Polytechnic Institute, Faculty of Physics and Mechanics, in 1996 and obtained her PhD in atmospheric physics from St. Petersburg State University in 2000. Since 1996, she has been working in the Theoretical Physics Division of Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute investigating the life-environment interactions in the framework of the biotic regulation concept founded by Prof. Victor Gorshkov. In co-authorship with V.G. Gorshkov, Anastassia formulated the concept of the biotic pump of atmospheric moisture highlighting key ecological feedbacks on atmospheric moisture transport (2007) and, in cooperation with an international team of colleagues, demonstrated the existence of life’s metabolic optimum (broadly universal rate of energy consumption across life’s kingdoms) (2008). Combining theoretical work with field observations, Anastassia spent over sixty months doing forest research in the Russian wilderness. Her current research interests focus on deepening the physical understanding of ecosystem feedbacks on the water cycle and moisture transport.
Name: Anastassia Makarieva
Other Links: Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute | Logo | Smart Biotic Pump | Logo |

Bio:
Maya Dutta is Outreach and Operations Manager at Biodiversity for a Livable Climate.  

I am an environmental advocate and ecosystem restorer working to spread understanding on the key role of biodiversity in shaping the climate and the water, carbon, nutrient and energy cycles we rely on. I am interested in climate change adaptation and mitigation and the ways that community-led ecosystem restoration can fight global climate change while improving the livelihood and equity of human communities.

#ERABoard
Comments:
MK managed a government-funded restoration effort in 2011, that covered 488 villages, over 500 projects, totalling 100,000 rainwater retention measures - resulting in 10 mil. m3 of water retention.

The assumption is that 2/3 or this water evaporated, and 1/3 created groundwater recharge. The Restoration was cancelled due to premature political changes in the government, that is why is was never measured. plan was 10 years.

MK's estimate is that this improved the watershed land area on 50,000 hectares.Presuming 0.8 tons of clean Carbon is sequestered in each hectar. > 0.8 x 2.94 tons of CO2 at the aread 50,000 hectares > 146,800 tons of CO2.

(Each restored hectar supported the photosynthesis intensity increase -> each hectar would increase the biomass yield by 2 tonnes.)

Going further, if carbon offset tax is valued at current 71 Euros, the value of the sequestration is 10.4 mil. Eur -> ROI is 4 years.

Bio:

Bio:
Sallie Calhoun owns and manages Paicines Ranch, a 7600-acre ranch in central California. She is also an impact investor, activist, and philanthropic funder in regenerative agriculture. Her work focuses on improving the health of agricultural soils and sequestering carbon in soil to mitigate climate change, while creating thriving communities. She is the founder of the No Regrets Initiative, which seeks to use a wide variety of forms of capital—human, natural, investment, and philanthropic—to affect change in the agricultural system.

Calhoun was born in Knoxville, TN and received a BSEE degree from Rice University. She worked in engineering and engineering management at a variety of high-tech firms for 25 years. From 1994 to 2000, she served as VP Operations and CFO for Globetrotter Software, Inc., which she co-owned with her husband Matt Christiano. In 2001, they sold the software company and purchased Paicines Ranch, which has been a working ranch since the mid-1800s. Since then she has operated the ranch implementing holistic management to improve the health of the soil, increase biodiversity, and produce grass-fed beef and lamb. Every year, dozens of ranchers, farmers, activists, philanthropists, sustainable agriculture investors and conservationists attend seminars at Paicines Ranch’s conference center.

She is the managing member of Cienega Capital, an impact investing firm, and the president of the Globetrotter Foundation, a family foundation. She has served on a variety of for-profit and non-profit boards, including Holistic Management International, Sierra Cascade Nursery, Agrarian Trust, and Estancia Beef. Sallie Calhoun loves to play tennis, hike, and travel.
Name: Sallie Calhoun

Bio:
About
Former 10 year member of the Board of Directors of the American Indian Institute (www.twocircles.org), 
She has also been working in the field of communication, including film and project development ;
and is an accomplished perma-culturalist who lived and farmed for many years in the French Pyrenees. 
She has resided in the U.S. since 2001 
In 2013, she created Waterock,L3C, (www.waterockl3c.com) a Limited Profit Company, organizing Training Workshops on long-forgotten techniques of rainwater harvesting and erosion control to desert-based Hopi and Navajo Tribal youth. 
Workshops are designed to train "trainers" who pass on their new information to others within their tribal communities. The Workshops have also led to the formation by a group of young Hopi participants in their "Hopi Raincatcher Team" which under Laurence's guidance has converted their new knowledge into employment opportunities, in cooperation with the Department of Water Resources of the Hopi Tribe.
Laurence is currently focused on the establishment of a "Profession of Land Healers" creating the Land Healers Foundation. She believes that climate change adaptation among Indigenous Populations requires the involvement of their youth, paid to be trained to work in their communities on land and water restoration, passing on their knowledge.
Her focus on Indigenous people is based on the fact that although their people have the smallest carbon footprint, they suffer more than any other communities the consequences of climate change and the degradation of Mother Earth They are the most likely to re-connect to their lands, as for they had been the natural stewards of our Planet from the dawn of civilization ;

From France to America, from the Pyrenees to Arizona, respectful of her maternal grandmother, a Chilean Mapuche Indian, we now see Laurence as self trained professional, dedicated to respect for Indigenous community life, environmental conservation, and the sanctity of spiritual values.
Name: Laurence de Bure

Bio:
Mark Shepard heads Restoration Agriculture Development and Forest Agriculture Nursery, but is most widely known as the author of the award-winning book, Restoration Agriculture: Real-World Permaculture for Farmers. Restoration Agriculture is based off his experiences at, New Forest Farm, and represents his belief in the ability of sustainably grown perennial food crops to feed us into “our resource-compromised future”.

New Forest Farm, located in Viola, Wisconsin, was once a worn-out rowcrop farm and has since become a 106-acre showcase commercial-scale perennial agricultural operation. It is considered by many to be one of the most ambitious sustainable agriculture projects in the United States. The farming system layout was founded on his innovations in engineering the runoff distribution, retention and control of water throughout the property. Next he implemented his take on adaptive mass-selection breeding with use of select perennial crops based off plant families abundant amongst the oak savanna, successional brushland, and eastern woodlands ecotypes that constituted the region prior to commercial agriculture. With the water management infrastructure in place, trees, shrubs, vines, canes, grasses, forbs and fungi were planted in likeness to their respective ecological niches, and organized to optimize efficiency in harvesting and management. Hazelnuts, chestnuts, walnuts, and apples are the primary woody crops. Various ongoing tree crops research sites are nested about the farm as well, and are an important feature in his adaptive, resilient restoration agriculture system.

Trained in mechanical engineering an ecology, Mark has combined these two passions to develop equipment and processes for the cultivation, harvesting and processing of forest-derived agricultural products. He is a certified permaculture designer and teaches agroforestry, permaculture, and his innovative systems of water management around the world.

You can learn more about Mark’s keyline adaptations and ways to optimize water across your property through is latest book, Water for Any Farm, or by attending our events and workshops available throughout the year.
Name: Mark Shepard

Bio:
Over 30 years of experience in responsible sustainable investing, specializing in biodiversity and the role of nature in regulating the Earth's climate. Adopting a systems thinking approach to tackle societal transitions

With over three decades of experience in sustainable and responsible institutional pension investing, I bring a wealth of expertise to the table. My areas of specialty include Asset Liability Management, investment strategy, governance, manager selection and monitoring, and product development. 

I have extensive expertise in the crucial role of biodiversity in regulating the Earth's temperature, as evidenced by my research with the Green Water Cools Collective (greenwatercools.org). Research has shown that human activities have significantly impacted nature's "green water" cycle, which is the cycle where plants, trees, and soil life play a critical role in controlling the Earth's cooling capacity.

Nevertheless, I believe that by gaining a better understanding of the "Green Water" function, we can revitalize our landscape in a smart and efficient manner, restore the Earth's cooling capacity, and meet the Paris climate goals within a single generation with positive social impact and lower costs. 

This will also lower our "assets at risk" for society and businesses and improve our investment decisions, as well as create a free social climate insurance. 

I am passionate about raising awareness about the cooling power of nature and eager to work with investors, governments, academic institutions, and businesses to integrate biodiversity into their value chains and investment processes, making them stronger in the process. 

With Innorbis, I am developing the "Future Coefficient," which compares social activities and investments against future goals, and provides insight into transition risks and opportunities for regulation and incentives that can achieve social goals with greater impact and efficiency.

Let's work together for a brighter future.

Bio:
Senior Consultant at The APAARI. 

He works to develop networking and sustainable partnerships between public-public, public-private and private-private sectors for knowledge sharing on experiences and best practices, to harness the potential of agricultural biotechnology for improving livelihoods of farmers in the Asia Pacific Region.

The Asia-Pacific Association of Agricultural Research Institutions (APAARI) is a unique voluntary, membership-based, self-mandated, apolitical and multi-stakeholder organization in the Asia-Pacific region. It promotes and strengthens agriculture and agri-food research and innovation systems through partnerships and collaboration, capacity development and advocacy for sustainable agricultural development in the region. Since its establishment in 1990, it has significantly contributed towards addressing agricultural research needs and enhancing food and nutritional security in the region. The close links, networks, partnerships and collaboration with stakeholders that APAARI has developed over the years, as well as its goodwill, authority and focus on results, make the Association a valuable actor in the region. The ultimate aim of APAARI is to help realizing sustainable development goals in Asia and the Pacific.

Bio:
A marketing and communications professional, having worked in the early part of my career with media owners, I moved into marketing services working with amongst others KLP, at Director level. In the early '90s I began my own agency, GJA Communications, covering most aspects of marketing services and working with a variety of blue-chip clients including, BT, the MoD, Porsche Cars (UK) and Nestle.
In 2007 after some consultancy projects, I moved in the 'green' sector joining 4Evergreen Technologies as Chairman, where we focussed our attention on advanced pyrolysis. In 2014 wanting to expand my knowledge of climate change and how to address it, I joined Envisionation. We are a high-level consultancy and communications organisation with a strong international influence garnered through our global scientific, political, legal and financial networks. We have created an holistic and integrated approach to the Whole Earth System which has culminated in the production of the Biosphere Restoration Plan.
Specialities: 'green'/ climate change technologies, diplomatic arena, business networking, communication strategy, fund raising, mentoring and interlocuter skills.

Bio:
Executive Director, Cuenca Los Ojos.  

As executive director, Jeremiah oversees both the U.S. and Mexico organizations. 

Originally from San Antonio, Texas, Jeremiah started in private law practice focused on water law, farm and ranch real estate law, and estate planning for agricultural families. He then served as the land transaction director for the Texas Agricultural Land Trust overseeing policy, outreach, and conservation easement transaction work throughout the state. Next, he served as the director of the Gulf Coast Cooperative Ecosystems Studies Unit for Texas A&M University’s Natural Resources Institute, which involved managing a research cooperative of 12 federal agencies and 50 university/NGO partners along the Gulf Coast from Texas to Florida. Prior to joining CLO, he served as the conservation director for the California Rangeland Trust helping landowners protect their lands throughout California.

A Texas A&M graduate and U.S. Marine Corps veteran, Jeremiah enjoys spending time with his family in the landscapes he is passionate about protecting.

Bio:
Ravenswood Media is an Academy Award nominated documentary production house based in Chicago. We specialize in environmental and conservation films, particularly about the Great Lakes. Our clients include both government agencies and not-for-profit organizations. Ravenswood Media exists because we believe that conservation and a healthy environment are critically important for a positive future of humankind.
I teach a wildlife filmmaking class in Rwanda. The class is designed for wildlife managers, rangers, guides and trackers. https://rwandawildlifefilmmaking.com 
The idea of the class was inspired by a quote from EO Wilson, "Bringing diverse experiences and points of view to problems raises the odds of success. Without diverse views we pay an opportunity cost, a cost in conservation not tried, in constraints not understood, in experiments not invented."

Bio:
Caroline McHale is the founder of VIVACE, a consultancy that supports and incubates initiatives relating to sustainability, solidarity and social impact.

She began her career as a research assistant at Columbia University's Earth Institute, followed by 15 years advising multinationals on complex legal, regulatory and strategic issues.

Her subject-matter expertise includes sustainability, energy, sustainable finance, social impact, corporate social responsibility, human rights, financial and environmental regulation, investment funds, joint ventures, multinationals, state-owned entities, supply chains, geopolitics and crisis management.

She has extensive emerging market experience (Azerbaijan, Brazil, China, Kazakhstan, Myanmar, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Uganda) and is an experienced manager in multi-cultural and geographically-dispersed contexts, overseeing people, projects and resources with an emphasis on excellence, collaboration, respect and accountability (French, English, Spanish and Italian spoken with professional fluency).

A lawyer admitted to practice in New York and Paris, she is an alum of Fordham Law School and Barnard College in New York, as well as ESCP Europe Business School in Paris, where she was awarded the Women in Energy Scholarship.

Bio:
Executive Director at Buckminster Fuller Institute https://www.bfi.org/
Transformations Architect
Ecological Designer
Regenerative Economist
Systems Scientist

Stuart grew up in the magnificent coastal temperate rainforests of Vancouver Island, and maintains a life-long passion to understand and sustain living systems. He brings 25 years of experience in regenerative design, finance, and systems and is a skilled design thinker, researcher, transformations architect, and leader of transdisciplinary initiatives. 

Stuart is the Co-Founder of Autopoiesis LLC, which applies complex systems models and frameworks to regenerate communities, ecosystems, and organizations with clients ranging from Confederated Tribes of Warm Springs to the International Living Future Institute. He was the architect for the Regenerative Communities Network, a project of Capital Institute, and served as its Director from 2018-20, supporting 15 bioregions on their journeys of place-sourced resilience & regeneration. From 2015-17, he was the Chief Scientist for the Smart Cities Council, where he developed knowledge frameworks and tools supporting the integration of smart technologies with urban sustainability and resilience. He served as a Transaction Manager and founding team member with Portland Family of Funds, an innovative sustainable community investment fund that has closed $5+ billion in transactions. While at the innovative non-profit Ecotrust, he led the development of the Reliable Prosperity framework for a regenerative bioregion, which provides a multi-scale map of patterns of natural, social, and economic capital. 

He is the co-author with Sim Van der Ryn of Ecological Design (Island Press, 1996/2007), addressing the whole systems integration of ecology and architecture, land-use planning, and product design, which has been translated into 3 languages and received 1,500+ citations. He received his doctorate in Applied Mathematics from U.C. Berkeley with a focus on Complex Systems and Ecological Economics. He has taught at Bainbridge Graduate Institute, U.C. Berkeley, Portland State University, and Naropa University. He has also presented and facilitated internationally for companies, government agencies, communities, and other clients.Stuart grew up in the magnificent coastal temperate rainforests of Vancouver Island, and maintains a life-long passion to understand and sustain living systems. Bio:
Companies are getting on the road to net zero emissions and measure their current sustainability level. Carbon Credits are a noisy business at the moment, many ways of getting it wrong. I assist in pointing in the right direction, match business activity with relevant emission reduction technology. Getting the most impact from investments in sustainability, manage reputational risk by choosing the appropriate methods. Leveraging low emission technology rather than buying carbon offsets or create insets that impact your Scope 1, 2 or 3 emission reporting. 

In ESG investments many exciting developments and new initiatives are out there in the market but many are unproven and given limited capacity the projects need to be rank ordered for feasibility, environmental and economic relevance as each next phase in the project will consume more and more resources. Structuring carbon capture projects to generate carbon credits to reduce emissions is a valuable contributor to mitigate climate change, being one of the many changes and new technologies that need to be put in place.

An experienced structured finance banker and risk manager arranged financing and risk transfer for many asset classes over the years. I have developed a keen insight in where an economically feasible common ground could be found. Structured finance has a number of conflicting interests and stakeholders that need to be brought together in a place and at a price that works for all parties. Also sufficient trust needs to be established that parties to the agreement have confidence that each party will perform its contracted obligations, usually by engaging external parties that verify such performance in order to create an objective measure of such compliance.
Name: Jan-Philip Wassenaar

Bio:
We face a pivotal challenge: protecting and preserving Africa’s and the world’s remaining biodiversity, endangered species, and wilderness areas. Addressing this requires a fresh, indigenous wilderness community-centered, socio-economic investment approach that is nature-positive, sustainable, and driven by innovative nature positive business development strategies and skills.

With a deep passion for rewilding and community conservation, I aim to leverage my expertise in Property Development, Hospitality, and Consumer Marketing in Southern Africa to foster radical collaboration among diverse stakeholders. 

Together, we can work with and empower Africa’s indigenous wilderness communities to restore and safeguard the continent’s remaining natural landscapes.

I am dedicated to actively contributing to the development of a sustainable and resilient African and global Conservation Economy.

Join me on a bespoke Social Impact Investment Travel Expedition, or reach out to explore opportunities to social impact invest in Orbis Investments or partner with RAIC (Rewilding Africa Impact Collaborative). 

Your support can help fund transformative rewilding and community development programs across Africa.
Name: James Arnott

Bio:
Muhangi Musinga is a dynamic innovator, grassroots creative, and expert in technology and community development based in Mubende, Uganda. As the founder of Fliptown DAO and the New Hometown World Movement, he is dedicated to leveraging technology and community collaboration to drive sustainable growth directly from the grassroots minds and involvement(Local solutions, Local Action). As a longstanding community and environmental activist, Muhangi leverages his intelligent imagination, arts, and diverse skills to foster local ingenuity and environmental regeneration. He has collaborated with grassroots organizations such as the Lwensambya Women’s Group, Munansi green Initiative, Noah Child Development Center, Children and Wives of Disabled Soldiers Association (CAWODISA), and Rural Development Action and Training Consult (RUDATCO) to train locals in clean energy and nature-based solutions. His dedication extends to promoting health through fitness programs, leading tropical tree planting campaigns, restoration of local watersheds and implementing various real-life and mindset strategies aimed at community betterment. 
For more, checkout https://www.fliptown.org or the "Living History of our Hometown" on Instagram @fliptowndao
Name: Muhangi Musinga

Bio:
Grazier and race horse breeder from Bylong in the Upper Hunter Valley in Australia.  Peter has gained fundamental insights to the natural functioning of the Australian landscape that leave him almost without peer. He has applied these insights in restoring his and other properties to fertility levels that he says existed upon European arrival in this country.

Over 30 years ago Peter, bought a run-down 2000 acre grazing property called Tarwyn Park, near Bylong in the Upper Hunter Valley. He then quietly set about testing the theories that he had been developing virtually ever since he was a child, growing up on a station near Broken Hill. By 1976 Peter Andrews claimed that the model he had set up on Tarwyn Park was an example of a sustainable agricultural system.
Name: Peter Andrews

Bio:
After six years of helping more than 60 SaaS businesses scale, I'm taking the critical lessons to the world of natural capital. My company, Blue Dot Project, aims to
1. Understand the system drivers that need to be changed
2. Raise lots of money to change them, and 
3. Take the learnings from growing SaaS businesses to accelerate the adoption rate of much-needed innovations that replace the methods that destroy nature.
Name: Eduardo Esparza

Bio:
I am deeply passionate about restoring living soil as a trim tab to create environmental, human, community and planetary health. I am also passionate about figuring out how to create a syntropic enterprise that leaves everything better for everyone, everywhere, as opposed to today’s entropic enterprises driven by profits. 

My regenerative worldview has come into full clarity the past four years as I continue to dive deep into learning about regenerative agriculture, circular economy, social equity and inclusion, regenerative governance, resilient communities, water stewardship in bioregions, biodiversity protection, conservation and restoration, renewable energy, human health, and the importance of warm data to be successful in all these areas. 

My passion for regenerative agriculture stems from personal experiences growing up on farms in Kenya and Denmark within the industrial/chemical farming community. Motivated by the impact of glyphosate on my father's health, I am dedicated to breaking down barriers for farmers to adopt transformational changes, promoting a regenerative worldview.

I am a passionate entrepreneur and I have experience from the startup phase, scaling and at the enterprise level. I spent the first 13 years of my career working in manufacturing in the food industry, aerospace, automotive, consumer electronics, computer software and hardware industries. Lean/Six Sigma methodologies were part of my toolbox to successfully optimize systems and processes. 

The next 12 years I worked as a Management Consultant for big firms (e.g. HPE) implementing large ERP systems (Oracle, PeopleSoft, Microsoft Dynamics, etc.) for big firms. I built on my successes in manufacturing and focused much more on helping people adopt the new software systems we were implementing, Organizational Change Management. I’ve worked in Asia, Europe, Canada, the US and am now in Central America.
Name: Marianne Wyne

Bio:
After several decades of nutrition consultation, the obvious truth that food is only as healthy as the soil in which it is grown has become indisputable to me. My concern grew as I saw patients who were becoming sicker, younger. The launching of Onchenda Open Global Food Cooperative was an effort to provide fresh food directly from farm to families, and to encourage farmers in the choice of healthy regenerative practices.

Rainbird Village, Benefit Corp. is in process of launching a new venture to build a Regenerative Pilot Community, including an institute of higher learning & practice, The Regenerative Arts and Ecologies Institute, including a Permaculture Research Institute and demonstration site, a Holistic Health Academy, Clinics and Destination Health Spa, the Regencubator, a regenerative business incubator and accelerator, with accompanying guest and student services and supporting community. 

Rainbird Development Company, is in process of launching it's first prototype community of the future, Rainbird Village, in Utah. We believe that many people can see that life as we live it now just isn't sustainable. Many of us would be willing to explore new ways of living life in harmony with nature and more provident in practice, if we knew how to do so in a reasonable manner. It is our desire to become an exploration leader, to make a very real improvement for people and the environment which supports us. 

My previous work has been with individuals, healthcare professionals, fitness centers, and corporations to improve health and nutrition awareness. I believe that vibrant health and fitness, as well as resistance to disease, may be facilitated through the habits of eating a well-balanced, whole food diet, the judicious use of supplements, getting adequate exercise, personal and social vigor. 

Specialties: Completed "Food as Medicine" course sponsored by Georgetown University Medical School, & the Center for Mind-Body Medicine (2008). 

Completed Leadership course at the Arbinger Institute.
Name: Colleen Dick

Bio: Owner/Manager, B Bar Ranch in Emigrant, Montana, USA.  Maryanne is also a trustee of the Charles Stewart Mott Foundation, which, among other areas, supports programs around the world that protect communities and the ecosystems upon which they depend.

Bio:
Mr. Paap is an expert in Capacity Building in the environmental sector. He currently works as a part-time agroforestry advisor for FarmTree B.V. Previously, he was working for Dutch municipalities in promotion of sustainable planning and building and energy transition. He has worked in various countries in West and Central Africa and is specialized in individual, organizational and systemic capacity building (resp. training/attitude change; mandates and structural changes; laws, policies, control, etc.). He also focused his attention on the Dutch environmental situation, worked to promote hydrogen as fuel and a landscape approach to the energy transition in various Dutch regions. His sabbatical, he is spent on a Spanish almond farm in Catalonia, where he promoted regenerative agriculture and agroforestry. He is now moving to the Limousin region in France, where he will be establishing a food forest.

Afforestation and Agroforestry

Project Management

Bio:
At Hou Uganda, we work with 35 youth corps to skill & train youths and small holder farmers on how to integrate tree planting into their daily farming systems. Through REFORESTATION AND BEEKEEPING PROJECT, we raise seedlings in our Reforestation centre as we carry on community mobilisation, sensitisation and training of the beneficiaries who later receive trees of different species (Fruit trees, medicinal trees, fodder for animals and reforestry trees) at absolutely no cost. The reason for REFORESTATION AND BEEKEEPING to work in concert was to keep this project an admirable one and self sustaining to address:-
1.Environmental restoration.
2.Income generation and self employment for farmers as they earn from the sales of fruit and Honey. We aim to create cooperatives for them to sale their produces collectively.
3.Food security and hunger management.
4. Soil quality improvement and fertility as most trees are nitrogen fixers like calliandra.
5. Resilience and sustainability will be viable because all these farmers will see a reason for the trees to stay put. 
6. Carbon sourcing and alternative household energy. All this has been done without external AID.
Name: Peter Taalye

Bio: GIS developer with considerable experience in an enterprise database environment. Specializes in Python programming but is also fairly proficient in C#. Has also worked with Unix commands and system calls. Knowledgeable in HTML and CSS, and is currently self-teaching the JavaScript API for ArcGIS. Previously had worked in a broad array of scientific fields, from Experimental Psychology to Immunology. Involved with humanist groups trying to restore science and reason to the educational curriculum. An ardent environmentalist who has both lobbied and protested against climate change and the destruction of Earth's natural resources.

Bio:
Dr. Katie Ross is an independent writer and researcher, with a background in ecology, renewable energy, regenerative agriculture, transdisciplinary research, and transformative sustainability learning. Knowing how stories hold, transmit and transform paradigms, Katie is keen to share stories of landscape and ocean regeneration.

Check out her most recent blog here, in a partnership with Climate Land Leaders. Read more.
