Bio:
Vision Holder/Founder for Climate Change & Consciousness and The TARA Approach

Dr. Stephanie Mines is a neuropsychologist whose unique understanding comes from her academic research as well as her extensive work in the field. Her stories of personal transformation have led many listeners to become deeply committed to the healing journey. Dr. Mines understands shock from every conceivable perspective. She has investigated it as a survivor, a professional, a healthcare provider, and as a trainer for staffs of institutions and agencies. 

Her blend of Western and Eastern modalities offers the best of both paradigms. She is devoted to ending the lineage of shock and trauma for individuals and the world.

Dr. Mines is the Program Director of the DOM Project, a non-profit organization dedicated to providing alternative health options for a broad spectrum of populations. As Director, she is responsible for disseminating information to communities in need, especially people suffering from illness that results from shock and trauma, survivors of domestic violence, families and children, and people living with neurodiversity including autism and other sensory integration challenges.

Dr. Mines’ books represent an overview of her mission to create a bottom up, empowerment based sustainable healthcare revolution. These include: We Are All in Shock; New Frontiers in Sensory Integration and most recently They Were Families: How War Comes Home.

See the website www.tara-approach.org for more information on the unique method Dr. Mines developed called The TARA Approach, combining an ancient Eastern Energy Healing technique with Western neuroscience. Dr. Mines currently teaches around the world as well as mentors clients online. 

Specialties: Advocacy Education for Healthcare Providers and Parents of Children and Youth with Special Needs, Training therapists in the treatment of trauma; educating parents about the prevention and treatment of early trauma; conducting seminars for healthcare professionals in the prevention and treatment of trauma and shock.

Dr. Mines’ Published Works:
NEURORESILIENCE (2016)
THEY WERE FAMILIES: HOW WAR COMES HOME (New Forums Press, 2015)
NEW FRONTIERS IN SENSORY INTEGRATION (New Forums Press, 2014)
WE ARE ALL IN SHOCK: How Overwhelming Experience Shatters You and What You Can Do About It (New Pages, 2006)
SEXUAL ABUSE/SACRED WOUND: Transforming Deep Trauma (Station Hill, 2000);
THE DREAMING CHILD: How Children Can Help Themselves Recover From Illness and Injury (Dom Project, 2003)

*Author of numerous articles on the treatment of trauma, including post-combat shock and domestic violence in the military environment.
Name: Stephanie Mines
updates: Posting: not allowed  ||  Email Pref: not allowed

Bio:
Enabling individuals and organizations to re-invest in and partner with Nature to restore ecosystems and water cycles, and thereby cool the earth.

Board member (President) of Biodiversity for a Livable Climate; Director, Washington DC Chapter of Bio4Climate; principal member, EcoRestoration Alliance.

Goal: Enable individuals and organizations to re-invest in and partner with Nature to restore ecosystems and water cycles, and thereby cool the earth.

I have had the good fortune to learn from and work with some very inspiring people, including Charlie Hall at Cornell (creator of "EROEI" and the field of Biophysical Economics), Gene Sharp at Harvard ("global guru" of nonviolent resistance), Jerry Barney at the Millennium Institute (lead of the U.S. government's Global 2000 Report, and creator of "Threshold 21" -- a multi-sector systems dynamics model to help nations make long-range planning decisions), and John Collins at the World Bank (who led a team that produced the Bank's first-ever report that included national estimates of human, social, and natural capital). More recently I have been inspired by the stories and experiences of my colleagues at Bio4Climate and those who have spoken at our many conferences. They have laid the important foundation that enabled the creation of the EcoRestoration Alliance. I am deeply grateful to them all.

Member, Maryland Dept. of Agriculture Soil Health Advisory Committee. Member ,Takoma Park Mobilization Environment Committee & Climate Action Coffee. Member, Montgomery County Climate Action Plan (CAP) Coalition. 

Retired from a senior administrative support position at Steptoe & Johnson, LLP. 

Past affiliations: Friends Community School (board president; treasurer), Center for Y2K & Society (director of communications), Millennium Institute (vice president), World Bank (consultant, Environment Dept., and Electronic Media Center), Institute for Global Communications (DC representative), Nonviolence International (project and executive director). Attended International Conference on Nonviolence at the Inter-University Centre, Dubrovnik (July 1983). Analyst at Cornell Theory Center/Cornell National Supercomputer Facility. Researcher/programmer at Cornell Global Carbon Project. Cornell BS in Operations Research & Industrial Engineering.

Bio:
I specialise in mid-market cross-border M&A and fundraising. With over 20 years of experience, I have built a network in the LP and GP community in Europe and the US. Extensive knowledge of deal origination, cross-border negotiations and closings. Institutional investors and PE-firms like to exchange ideas with us about current off-radar investments in Europe including Impact. I'm currently the managing partner at AMA International and a board member of ACS Partners - a global M&A boutique network. 

I also engaged in the Global Impact developing sustainable infrastructure investments. I work on the global decarbonisation projects matching investors with Green and Blue Initiatives. Heading Corporate Development part of Re'Planet Capital. 

In addition, I enjoy spending time exploring cultures with my family. Father of three and a happy husband.

Bio:
Laura P. Burke Pérez-Arce works in the fields of wildlands conservation and community advocacy. 

Let´s re-green the planet, defend the wilderness and mobilize every sector, institution, group, and individual to participate within an economy for conservation and healthy resilient communities and ecosystems. Grupo Ecológico Sierra Gorda IAP is the living laboratory for implementing a bioregional regenerative model involving the local landowners of high biodiversity within a UNESCO MaB Biosphere Reserve, Sierra Gorda, Mexico.
Viva Sierra Gorda is an advocacy, philanthropy and technology transfer project of Earth Island Institute, providing international promotion, support and solidarity to grassroots organizations that work in and around the Sierra Gorda Biosphere Reserve in Queretaro State in central Mexico. My Mom and I founded VSG in 2004.

Specialties: Carbon offsets for individuals, events and travel; Outreach & Public Relations, Fundraising, Grassroots advocacy; Community-based rural tourism
Comments: Mutual friend of Russ's, She can bring in many US Indian tribes who are willing and able to restore their reservations once they get funding.

Bio:
Working towards a new "togetherness". 

Helping generate a flow of shared meaning through dialogue and holding space for the needed and resulting individual and collective actions to emerge. We each need to transform, not just change. Together.

Supporting individuals as mirroring coach and groups, such as the Art of Forests Alliance, as community lead.

With a commitment to environmental and social activism - co-founder of XR Catalysers bringing dialogue to places of power and influence since August 2019. Co-coordinator of Plastics Rebellion since August 2022, aiming to end plastic production and support full re-usage and recycle of plastic already produced.

Our world rooted in division and competition is dying. The future calling us is in unity and equity. Let's foster the courage to change and transition from the old world to the new world that is calling us together. 

Starting with the nurturing of friendship and reciprocity. Be part of the change that is calling each and all of us. Connect with me and let's explore how we might support one another.
Name: Caroline Pakel

Bio: Eduardo Marino is a Colombian restoration advocate who proposes "Greening the Central American Pacific Coast" to address the mass migration of millions of Central Americans—since 2018—by connecting it to desertification and soil degradation across the Pacific dry corridor from Panama to California. Eduardo proposes large-scale reforestation and water cycle restoration across this 180-million-person region to restore agricultural productivity and address root causes of forced migration. His work demonstrates the inseparable relationship between ecosystem health and human displacement, showing how ecological restoration can address humanitarian crises at their source.
Last event: wrote to him and his son March 30 2025
Name: Eduardo Marino

Bio:
About
Kethia Sanon (Calixte) is a graduate of the Colin Powell School's Class of 2023, holding a Bachelor's degree in International Development and Psychology, complemented by minors in Public Policy and Economics. Her academic and professional journey has equipped her with a distinctive and comprehensive perspective on both local and global issues.

Throughout her academic pursuit, she actively engaged in numerous fellowships and internships, notably the two-year Colin Powell Fellowship in Leadership and Public Service, the S Jay Levy Fellowship for Future Leaders, and was a Paul Weiss legal scholar within the Honors Program in Legal Studies at the Colin Powell School. These transformative experiences led her to intern in Washington, D.C. as an Archival research intern under the supervision of Columbia University’s Luca Falciola. Other experiences include being a public policy intern with New York City Council member Farah Louis, where she gained invaluable insights into the world of public policy. Furthermore, Kethia was the recipient of the Cedric Robinson Award in International Studies and the spring 2023 Rose and Herbert Rubin Award, allowing contribution to sustainable development research, collaborating with grassroots organizations like REDES (Réseau Pour l’Emergence et le Dévelopement des Ecovillages au Sahel) as an independent researcher. These diverse and enriching experiences have not only facilitated her development of a multi-dimensional understanding but have also ignited her unwavering passion for research and a profound appreciation for the fundamental role of law in constructing and sustaining our communities.
Name: Kethia Calixte

Bio:
I am a Legacy Impact Advisor, supporting individuals, organizations, and sponsors/investors worldwide in creating and implementing projects that conserve and regenerate natural and human ecosystems, for the future of the world and the planet. I have large experience in design, communication, and strategy, as well as a certification as a Climate Reality Leader from The Climate Reality Project.

My professional journey has been shaped by my passion for networking, sensing the future, and manifesting the embodied gifts. I love human evolutionary capacity and its inter-being potential. I have been involved in various causes, such as sustainability, climate change mitigation, grass-roots initiatives, community activation, biodiversity regeneration, cultural design, and organizational development. I am also a co-founder and board member of Fundação Terra Agora, a foundation that aims to transform the cycle of buying and selling into a cycle of conservation and regeneration.
Name: Claudian Dobos

Bio: Mary Minton is interested in water restoration. She recently relocated to Washington State near the Salish Sea. As she describes herself: "Water is my middle name... It's why we live on this blue planet." Mary participates in ERA to learn from practitioners and deepen her understanding of watershed and marine restoration, bringing curiosity and commitment to water-centered ecological work.
Name: Mary Minton

Bio: Ansiima Casinga Rolande is a passionate permaculture and nutrition trainer dedicated to empowering refugee communities. With deep experience in the challenges refugees face, she founded FOLONA (For the Love of Nature). This community-based organization addresses vital issues such as permaculture implementation, women's empowerment, climate change action, and reproductive health.
Name: Ansima Casinga Rolande

Bio: I am a Masters student in Organizational Development and am focusing on sustainability in business. Unfortunately the overarching model in my program and business school is profit-focused "sustainability' initiatives that hijack environmental language to describe (and continue to profit from) business as usual. I am interested in developing REAL interventions and processes to shift people and organizations into a regenerative and restorative approach, and to provide resources and support to do so. I would like to connect with the network to learn more and collaborate on how to seed this information on regeneration into companies that have the resources to invest in real restoration.

Bio:
Plants are my passion. Farming, gardening, wildcrafting, promoting. Started Friends of the Trees Society in 1978, inspired by Richard St. Barbe Baker of Men of the Trees (established 1921). The goals of Friends of the Trees Society are to double the world's forest cover and double the weight of the biomass on the planet (at least). 

Permaculture teaching, organizing and networking.
Comments:
Had a great conversation today about his work and joining the ERA.
He is located in la ceiba, honduras
Has developed his Igna agroforestry system over decades, helping over 420 families with 2,500 hectares, planting over 4.5million trees, and influencing the restoration of millions of hectares of land in 15 countries. He has a great reputation with the locas, having hundreds of families asking to take part in his program after seeing the resilience of the land to droughts and hurricanes.
His method is the last hope to the people of these regions where the soils have been depleted from hundreds of years of slash and burn agriculture. The soil will no longer hold onto synthetic fertilizers and drains nutrients into the Carribean.
His plans for the next stage in his development involve replicating what's already happening in the river catchment, set up "cells" that demonstrate the process, then allow them to multiply and develop while keeping the chain of command to a minimum.
Currently, his land influence spans 420 families, with 2,500 hectares using his model that draws down ~30 tons of co2 per hetare over 12 years. His current growth is about 40 families per year, each having 8 hectares. Cumulitively, he estimates 300,000 tons of co2 are being sequestered per year.
Mike is a great storyteller who is willing to share and explain his model to us
Name: Michael Pilarski

Bio:
Hello, I'm an elder with a four decade background in psychology, education and academic futures studies. 
I founded Global Futures Education to offer high-level online education for entrepreneurs, professionals and executives wanting to confront and manage the intensifying global challenges of the 21st Century - especially climate crisis - and to find solutions. My "Global Futures of Climate" (Online Course) is a comprehensive, science-based, integrative self-paced course focused strongly nature-based solutions and aligned to the UN SDGs. I'd love to explore collaboration and be on your map of nature-based solutions to climate crisis.
Name: Jennifer Gidley

Bio:
Current Project: I am working together with the Ghetto Research Lab in Uganda, Kampala on transforming a slum through sustainable practices. Here I function as Sustainable Designer and Sustainability Consultant, where I initiate workshops around food insecurity, floods, sustainable housing. As a result the project is working towards building a food forest in the slum through remediation efforts of contaminated landscapes, bamboo housing which is resilient against floodings and a skatepark which is used strategically to mitigate floods. I am always happy to connect and talk about possible partnerships or jobs. 
Growing up in one of the major cities in Germany, Cologne, I have always been drawn to the abundance in natural environments. The “city forest” and the” greenbelt” in the middle of the city centre are some examples, cologne is blessed with. Immersing yourself in nature helps to release stress. Natural environments can strategically be planned to enhance eco-health such as human well-being and facilitate the reconnect to nature, which is highly needed in our current form of society. A nature centred approach is a holistic form which encompasses a human centred notion on one side and on the other hand also allows room for Biodiversity as well as natural solutions for climate adaptation to be designed. I am interested in regenerative agriculture, sustainable transitions, resilience-design, co-design, community-centred design, social-entrepeneurship, nature, cities, people, nature-based solutions.

Bio:
Sally Dodge was most recently Northeast Community Development Manager, and a member of the Board of Directors, at Iroquois Valley Farmland REIT, an organic food and farmland impact investment company. Iroquois Valley Farms' farmer and investor partners are working together through organic and regenerative agricultural practices to provide heathy soils, healthy food, and to slow climate change through soil carbon sequestration. She retired from this position in late 2019. 

Sally is a farmer, successful business owner, creative entrepreneur, experienced fundraiser and grant writer, resourceful and energetic community activist, senior career counselor and outplacement professional, and property manager. She is owner of Old Quarry Hill, LLC, a short-term rental property on her family's farm in Pownal Vermont. From 1975 to 1986 she raised beef cattle on that property, and had the largest herd of Beefalo east of the Mississippi at that time. She is a partner in the Mountain Goat, an outdoor outfitting retail store in Manchester. In the late 80s she created "Taste Vermont", and event that linked chefs and farmers, and was a catalyst for the Farm to Table movement in Vermont. She was Executive Director of the North Shire Museum and History Center, in Manchester, Vermont from 2002 to 2006. There she developed hands-on programs, and created the Manchester Farmers Market and the indoor WinterMarket, both successful seasonal retail venues for area farmers and food producers. She has consulted with small manufacturing companies to improve marketing, sales, and operations, and has spent a number of years as a successful career counselor and outplacement professional. She has served on many boards and has worked with diverse organizations, including agricultural advocacy, conservation, environmental groups, and charitable foundations. She served on the board or fundraising committees of the Vermont Land Trust for 18 years. She is currently on the boards of the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation, and the Education Committee of the Wildlife Conservation Society.

Sally is active in supporting soil health, restoring the Soil Carbon Sponge, and promoting Eco-Restoration as a way to mitigate climate change. 

Specialties: Supporting and advancing the locally-grown farm and food industry in Vermont. Grant-writing and fundraising. Entrepreneurial organization.
Name: Sally Dodge

Bio: As the Director of Gardens & Landscapes at Mount Auburn Cemetery, I oversee the maintenance of the shrubs and perennials in the gardens and natural areas across the cemetery. It's an honor to be a steward of a landscape that inspires all who visit, comforts the bereaved, and commemorates the dead. I collaborate with a team of directors in the Horticulture & Landscape department to maintain this landscape of exceptional beauty. I have been an active board member of the Ecological Landscape Alliance since 2016. My experience includes designing, installing and maintaining native gardens, managing invasive plants, maintaining green infrastructure facilities, and restoring native landscapes. I love seeing wildlife interactions with new plantings, learning new plants, and staring deeply into the eyes of a flower!
Name: Rie Macchiarolo

Bio:
Storyteller/Teacher/Coach.

Judith Black’s traditional and original stories have rocked laughing audiences to their feet. A creator and teller of tales for over 30 years, Judith’s stories wrestle with everything from familial dysfunction, to the search for spiritual connection, to the questionable joys of aging. Her background in theater, early childhood development, political activism, the the wryly observed life, inform her work. Recipient of the Oracle: Circle of Excellence, the most coveted award in storytelling, Judith has been featured on stages as far reaching as The Montreal Comedy Festival, The National Storytelling Festival, The Smithsonian Institution, Hebrew University in Jerusalem, the National Art Museum in Cape Town, and NPR. She has created stories for the US Department of the Interior, NPR, The Mass. Foundation for the Humanities, and many others. A graduate of Wheelock College, she holds a degree in Early Childhood Education and has been an adjunct faculty member at Lesley University for twenty years. For more information about Judith’s work: www.storiesalive.com and www.tellingstoriestochildren.com

At home she’s the nurturer of an organic garden, sings in a women’s chorus, raised a U.S. Marine, and is married with Michael Elkin. She developed, with her friend Dr. Jack Weltner, and runs a peer mentoring program, Bridging Lives which matches high school teens with elementary students who could use some additional TLC in their lives. She meets with the teens bi-monthly and orchestrates 4 annual programs for the entire population. She also cooks monthly at Lifebridge.
Name: Judith Black
updates: Posting: not allowed  ||  Email Pref: not allowed

Bio:
Steve Apfelbaum, the founder of Applied Ecological Services in Brodhead, WI, has been a full-time research and consulting ecologist with AES since 1978 when he founded the company and in 2021 merged with Resource Environmental Solutions (RES). Steve has conducted ecological research projects in most biomes of North America, and since the early 1980s he has been one of the leading consultants in the U.S. in ecological restoration programs. Apfelbaum is trained as an animal and plant ecologist with graduate studies at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign where he earned his MS Degree in Ecological and Biological Sciences in 1978. He has been a scientist in hundreds of field ecological projects and data analysis projects.

During his career, Mr. Apfelbaum has authored or co-authored hundreds of technical studies, reports, ecological program plans, restoration plans, and monitoring and compliance reports for research projects and for regulatory program reporting. In recent years, his focus has been in soil carbon research and directing large soil carbon projects in Canada, Palouse Region, and throughout the country. He has worked closely with hydrologists to understand landscape-scale hydrologic changes associated with land settlement in the Midwestern U.S. This work has direct application to many millions of acres in North America and elsewhere. Mr. Apfelbaum has also presented results of his study of ecological restoration at hundreds of seminars and courses around the world and is a much sought-after speaker at educational events focusing on soil carbon, regenerative agriculture, ecological restoration, alternative storm water management, and conservation development.

Apfelbaum’s latest book, “Restoring Ecological Health to Your Land” (Island Press) and his personal account of thirty years of restoring their Wisconsin farm, in “Natures Second Chance” (Beacon press) have received a range of awards, including rave reviews in the New York Times and elsewhere. The later book has been recognized as one of the top ten environmental books of 2009 and best books for people to personally learn about what they can do to address climate change. Apfelbaum teaches at the Harvard Graduate School of Design a course on the future of coastal systems and regenerative agriculture and holds adjunct professorships and lectureships at several other universities.

Bio:
About
I am a farmer, researcher, writer, and champion of the regenerative agricultural movement. I have worked in production agriculture for over 10 years. I have extensive experience working in diverse systems at varying scales, implementing large-scale regenerative transition, and developing regional regenerative supply chains. For the past four years, I have been leading a non-profit research organization, Hudson Carbon, working on advancing science and policy to support landscape-scale regenerative food system transition across the globe.

I am a systems thinker who is passionate about food systems, ecology, and ecosystem regeneration. I am dedicated to finding solutions that harmonize the production of food, feed, fiber, fuel, and medicine with the complex interactions and cycles that define healthy ecosystems.

Bio:
I am the Science Outreach Coordinator at Rainforest Connection (RFCx), a non-profit that builds and deploys scalable, open acoustic monitoring systems that can halt illegal logging and poaching, and can enable biodiversity measurement and monitoring. RFCx also hosts Arbimon, a cloud-based analytical tool for visualizing, analyzing, and interpreting bioacoustic data. 

As part of my work in the conservation tech space, I co-developed the Conservation Tech Directory with Gracie Ermie - https://conservationtech.directory/. This compiles organizations, companies, networks, opportunities and resources within the space into a centralized database.

I am also finishing up my PhD at the City University of New York (CUNY). For my dissertation research, I study developed a passive acoustic monitoring and machine learning pipeline to survey the Critically Endangered black-and-white ruffed lemur across their fragmented range in southeastern Madagascar.

Bio:
Born and raised on the west side of Kansas City’s 5th District. Have worked in & around the Kansas City metro; working particularly with the youth, helping hundreds of children unlock their physical, intellectual, & creative potentials in a variety of capacities. 

Received bachelor’s degree in multimedia arts from the Kansas City Art Institute in 2006. Original goal for attending art school was to write movie scripts & be a director, my creative muse didn’t find this path satisfactory. The 'new found Artist within' was drawn to serving rather than ‘entertaining’ the masses. 

Understanding the need for structural change that starts within the most basic communities: the neighborhoods, is most important.

Since its founding, MY REGION WINS! (MRW!) has dedicated itself to empowering the neighborhoods of Kansas City towards self-sufficiency, natural stewardship, & grassroots pushes for socioeconomic change. 

In 2019, became a certified community coach through the prestigious Fowler International Academy of Professional Coaching. My vision for Kansas City, Missouri is one that works for all, & emphasizes artistic advancement & environmental consciousness.

In 2021, Grinnell College recognized me as the “Innovator to Watch” (Google it)

Dedicated to the progression of my dream that has been decades in the making: a sustainable cultural future for Kansas City, & the world.

MY REGION WINS! is not only for dreams; it was founded by one (ME). Being an Artist, a Creator, a Dreamer, & one who is environmentally conscious, it is vitally important to have access to resources & critiques. My dream is to be someone who was known for making an impact, by sparking amazing ideas that better life.

Please visit www.myregionwins.org
Kansas City's Creative Nonprofit Organization

MISSION: Transcend everyday challenges by using the Arts to nurture creative & undeveloped ideas that shape society.

VISION: For the Arts & Nature to have a larger influence on our society & our future generations.

SERVICES: MRW! helps companies support their employees' aspirational goals & dreams, to see their employees' greatness, & champion their employees' vision of a better earth, humanity & self.

PROJECTS & PROGRAMS: Demonstrate & display ideal environmental & social practices to increase the appreciation & understanding for them to influence better expedited decision making.

Bio:
Michal Kravčík is an internationally recognized Slovak water scientist, ASHOKA fellow, and co-author of A New Water Paradigm: Water for the Recovery of the Climate, which emphasizes  hydrologic cycles in addressing climate change. He is also a founding member and chairman of Slovakia’s NGO People and Water.  In 1999, Kravčík was awarded the Goldman Environmental Prize for his contributions to the water management of the Torysa River after galvanizing support to halt a dam planned during the Communist era by proposing effective democratic alternatives, including smaller dams, decentralized water management, and restored farmlands.

Kravčík took his ideas to the national level in 1998, helping to organize a non-partisan national voter education campaign that resulted in unprecedented citizen participation in national elections. People and Water organized the Village and Democracy project in 164 villages in the Levoca mountain region to support democratic processes and build a sustainable open society. Kravčík and People and Water have continued to work toward integrated river basin management in the region via the sustainable development programs “Villages for the Third Millennium”, “Water for the Third Millenium” and “Blue Alternative”.  And check out Michal’s  Global Action Plan for the Restoration of Natural Water Cycles and Climate!

Name: Folorunso Dayo Oluwafemi

Bio:
MD of Envisionation Ltd www.envisionation.org an organisation dedicated to the holistic understanding of and solutions to global environmental degradation. I lead a team of strategic systems thinkers and scientists focused on the timing and intensity of climate change with the objective of promoting tangible countermeasures. 
Envisionation is engaged in translating climate science into business language and commercial risk assessments. Our findings confirm that climate change and environmental degradation are going to be the defining driving forces of this century and no business or individual will remain untouched. Emissions reductions alone are going to be insufficient to maintain a stable climate, accordingly we are working with all forms of renewable energy and carbon draw-down initiatives. We believe that essential retooling of the Earth’s energy infrastructure and a global environmental restoration project, present the greatest commercial opportunity that has ever existed. 
Envisionation offers consultancy services to the boards of corporations assisting them to identify their individual asset risks, corporate and personal contingent liabilities to customers, staff and shareholders. And opportunities for skills and asset transference into the countermeasures markets. 

Background
I am the yachtsman turned international property developer. I have delivered marinas, ports and resorts in the Mediterranean and Caribbean. I gained first-hand experience of climate change when category five hurricane Ivan struck Grenada in 2004. This led me to establish Envisionation Ltd Grenada as a consulting and development company geared towards sustainable solutions for small island states. Returning to the UK in 2010 together with Nick Breeze we set up Envisionation to communicate climate change science and solutions.

Bio:
Resilience & Regeneration LLC  La Follette School of Public Affairs at UW-Madison

Drawing from more than a decade in the regenerative and resilient communities movement, I support communities, projects and people to prepare to thrive in an uncertain future. My skills include organizational strategy, development and movement building; research, policy analysis, writing and editing; community organizing and facilitation; business planning and entrepreneurship; ecological and community design; regenerative economics; bioregionalism; fundraising; and more. I co-founded the Fertile Edge Community Land Trust based in Colorado's Western Slope, dedicated to addressing ecological regeneration and agriculture as well as providing affordable, ecolocially-designed housing. I'm currently contracting for the Town of Paonia, where I live, to produce the Town's first Master Plan since 1996. In this role I'm leading a team of local professionals to conduct robust background research and community engagement to inform a plan that will guide our community into a thriving and resilient future.

Bio:
Founder, Hands On Permaculture
https://www.handsonpermaculture.org/about/

Charlotte Anthony started out as a biodynamic farmer more than 45 years ago. Most recently she spearheaded the volunteer organization, Victory Gardens for All, which installed 650 gardens in Eugene, Oregon from 2008 – 2012. Charlotte has recently moved to Ananda Laurelwood in Gaston, Oregon to start-up food production for the emerging eco-village. Charlotte’s philosophy is that most of us long for connection; “I live with the earth, the plants, the trees, the animals around me. They tell me what they need and, by providing it as I can, I receive a sense of belonging.”

Charlotte comes from a long line of Danish peasants and has gardened since she was a child. In 1967 she did her first major garden while living in a back to the land community in New Hampshire. She picked and pruned for several commercial orchards, and converted a long-abandoned 15-acre apple orchard to the first organic apple orchard serving health food markets in Boston. During this time she studied biodynamic methodologies and was asked to present on organic apple growing at several events of the New England Apple Growers Association and the New Hampshire Extension Service.

Victory Gardens

In 1970 she was asked to join an aspiring biodynamic farm in New Hampshire where 15 acres of vegetables were grown and marketed through the Natural Organic Farming Association which she helped to form. Due to her natural farming ability, including knowing when to plant, when to harvest, how to observe the plants and the soils, and what to do when they were not growing well, she soon was asked to manage the farm.

In 1974, she planted a biodynamic fruit orchard at the farm in New Hampshire. The owner of a 300-acre commercial orchard where she had been managing apple picking crews and pruning crews came to observe the new organic orchard. Soon after working with Charlotte on her organic orchard, he became one of the first commercial apple growers to use integrated pest management, with good returns.

In 1975 she was called to diversify her skills by attending chiropractic school and learning to work with humans. In 1980 just before she started practice as a chiropractor, she had a landmark project at a farm in New Hampshire for her spiritual community where she fed 5000 people with most of their food including tomatoes, corn, and beans in July after starting just that spring. Having all this food ready in July was so unheard of that they wrote about it in the Concord newspaper, the big city more than an hour away. Charlotte started her chiropractic practice in 1980 in Oregon. She had great success rates in chiropractic, receiving referrals from doctors in the surrounding 5 states for chronic problems including cancer. However, she had a strong sense that patients would do better if they learned to listen to their intuition and not yield authority to a doctor. In 1985 she again grew a major garden for her meditation retreat in New Hampshire, and in 1986 she moved to Minnesota and began another career, buying and remodeling old homes. In 2002, her mother died after a relatively benign stroke and 17 medical errors. She started an advocacy program so that people might know how to claim their own health and advocate for their loved ones.

In 2002, Charlotte went to Colorado to do a large CSA, and then in 2004 to New Orleans to serve after Hurricane Katrina. In addition to working on a bioremediation project, she became the on-site coordinator for the permaculture gardens which had been severely damaged after Katrina, where she worked with as many as 80 volunteers a day who had come to help after Katrina. In 2007, Charlotte began the Victory Gardens project in Eugene, Oregon. “We bring 4-6 volunteers and start a 10 x 16 or larger garden, complete with soil amendments, compost, and plants in 4-5 hours. We use a no-till gardening system. The folks who receive gardens pay it forward by working on the next gardens. Through November of 2011, we completed 650 gardens in the Eugene area. Folks pay $75.00 for their new garden. The gardens are as sustainable as we can make them, including dynamic accumulators, medicinal plants, either in the garden space or near the garden space, connected with mycorrhizals.”

“Victory Gardens for All grows all the plant starts for the program. We added food forests to the victory garden program in 2010. We have 2000 fruit trees growing on several different properties which we have grafted onto rootstock with volunteers from the community. The intention for these plants is to start food forests and to plant in people’s yards and in places with public access. The food forest is a very diversified orchard with fruit and nut trees, and companion planted with dynamic accumulators, medicinal plants, and all types of perennials including vines, root crops, and berry bushes. We also plant some self-seeding annuals such as potatoes, summer and winter squash, kale, and arugula.”

Charlotte has written two books: Surviving Health Care in America and 101 Ways to Supercharge Your Energy.

The Mother Who Plants Trees: “Just before my 69th birthday I awakened in the night hearing a message which said I was to be in India by November 22, 2013. I had less than a month to get ready. One miracle following another I got on the plane for India on November 25, 2013.

Once in India, I was led on an odyssey crisscrossing India many times leading me to farmers who were running out of water to farm. Ultimately I learned that in India there was a 10,000-year history of sustainable agriculture. I realized that my whole life had led me to this point. By using dryland agriculture traditional Indians had been using a way of farming that could bring back our ecosystems around the world, thereby stopping floods, droughts, and fires. We could stop using chemicals, use permaculture and natural farming, plant trees, and practice what is called water conservation in India (swales, key lines, ponds, etc.) This is called restorative agroforestry, or agroecology and a new name is carbon farming. The main difference is these technics and the techniques which have destroyed ecosystems around the world, is these techniques work with soil biologies. Amazingly these methods use almost zero inputs and get higher yields, so they can really help the farmers. We are enheartened to see that there are at least 5 consultancy firms helping industrial farmers apply biological technics on their farm.
Comments: Charlotte Anthony +1 458 245 6309  cell  /  541 579 8607  www.handsonpermaculture.org

Bio:
Senior Consultant (Freelance) - Let's Cool the Planet Now! Started out as a philosopher, an adventurer, and (co-)founder of several adventure travel companies. I am an Earth systems thinker, who realizes this is the most consequential decade in the history of humanity. We are in a race to reinvent the way we live on this planet sustainably and with justice and respect for all and all life. The solution to climate change is much more simple than people realize. The answer is in managing the hydrological cycle, change the focus toward water. CO2 is a problem, but not the main one. The main driver of climate change and extreme weather is the destruction of the cooling power of nature and the degradation of land.  I am now a full time environmentalist involved in landscape restoration and new cultural models to reintegrate nature into our thinking and rediscover the vast knowledge the indigenous peoples of the world have held safe for humanity. Worldwide 2 billion hectares are degraded land that could be revitalized, helping significantly to combat climate change, protecting biodiversity, food production, water cycle and reconnect us humans to mother Nature. Available as project manager or consultant to transform local economies and companies after the pandemic. Let us retrieve that happy world that lives in our hearts. It is what we need most these days. But we have become entangled in a net of complexity.

Bio:
From 1987 to 1997 and since 2010, I have served as Co-Founder and General Director of Grupo Ecologico Sierra Gorda. Between 1997 and 2010, I was the Federal Director of the Sierra Gorda Biosphere Reserve, and from 2001 to 2009, I acted as the Regional Coordinator for a Full Size Global Environment Facility Project. In recognition of my contributions, I have received numerous awards, including the National Ecology Award (Mexico, 2000), the Rolex Prize for Enterprise (2002), and the BBVA Foundation Prize for Conservation (2007), among others.

Grupo Ecologico Sierra Gorda, founded by local citizens in 1987, operates the Biodiversity in the Sierra Gorda Biosphere Reserve Project. Our mission is to conserve natural resources and promote sustainable development in the Sierra Gorda region by uniting citizens and institutional efforts. We provide environmental education to 18,000 young people and support community development for women in 127 communities. Additionally, we are developing a conservation economy through payment for environmental services to forest owners.

Bio:
I work in consulting. Consultant" can cover a whole host things, but for me, it means working with state and county governments, particularly in the adult education and training space. In my work I’ve trained thousands of adults, assessed learning needs, built curriculums and a whole lot of technical training content, designed new business processes + fixed them in response to feedback from the end user, managed teams of trainers, and assessed whether or not all that learning is actually working. I get to meet, interview, and learn from state and county employees who work insanely hard to help people in their communities. 

I’m stoked about all the new learning technologies these days, but my personal soap box is that we spend too much time at the theoretical design level and not enough time listening to the person actually doing the day-to-day work, whether that’s a call center agent or a contact tracer. 

Things I love to do: Build and deliver trainings - give presentations to large groups of people - coach others - synthesize information - fix PowerPoint presentations so they're stories instead of word vomit - come up with new ideas - learn new things. 

Particular areas of interest: Adult learning theory. Conservation and land policy in Massachusetts. Sustainability and green infrastructure for climate change resiliency. Anything that lets me deploy the skills listed in my "Things I Love to Do" paragraph.
Comments: Cambridge via Cole Enos

Name: Craig Erickson

Bio:
Nativien ~ Intercultural Models - Living Systems - Impact & Regenerative Investing - Collective Intelligence

Marc Thibault has been involved in the social and environmental impact sphere for over 20 years as an entrepreneur, system thinker and policy influencer covering a wide span of industries and issues developing novel solutions requiring human-centered design while integrating environmental and social concerns. After pioneering for 10 years model-driven decision support systems and designing web-based cooperative DSS, Mr. Thibault started focusing on solving environmental health issues working across the private, public and non-profit sectors to a) provide alternative to toxic chemicals, b) influence policies to better protect our children and c) support sound non-profits advance their mission, becoming a strong advocate for hybrid corporations such as B-Corps along the way. In 2012, Mr. Thibault visited the Ecuadorian Amazon Rainforest and saw a need for new models, ones that put Indigenous Peoples at the center. By 2013, he was already testing different models using intercultural and biocultural approaches and in 2021 started Nativien, an Indigenous-centered hybrid organization producing health remedies using local medicinal plants as a vehicle to preserve Indigenous Traditional Ecological Knowledge and the Forest. 

Nativien was selected a Top Uplink Innovator WEF/ 1 Trillion Tree Amazon Bio-Economy Challenge.
Comments: friend of Rob de Laet
Name: Marc Thibault
updates: Posting: not allowed  ||  Email Pref: not allowed

Bio:
Heather Wilber is an NSF postdoctoral fellow working with Prof. Gunnar Martinsson's research group in numerical analysis and computational mathematics. She graduated from Cornell University with her PhD in Applied Mathematics in May 2021, where she was supervised by Prof. Alex Townsend. Prior to that, she earned her M.S. in Applied Mathematics under the supervision of Prof. Grady Wright at Boise State University.

Heather's work involves problems at the interface of approximation theory, computational mathematics, and scientific computing. This includes the development and analysis of low rank approximation methods, direct solvers for partial differential equations, algorithms for solving linear matrix equations and evaluating functions of matrices, and robust algorithms for computing with rational approximations to functions.
Name: Heather Wilber

Bio: Alex has worked intensively in production including multimedia educational software development, corporate digital imaging, 3-D animation and experimental film and video. She holds a PhD in information and Communication Sciences from Paris University. She is now trying to understand the societal and economic impact informal DIY  and social media cultures have on children and formal education.
Name: Alex Bal

Bio:
Awesome mom who raised 4 future leaders and innovators of humanity. Climate Advocate. Software developer. Database engineer. Former US Senatorial candidate. Rancher wannabe. Data privacy advocate. Obsessed with all things global, including education systems, housing systems, economic systems, and how to help people live their lives how they want and need to.

Water is the #1 greenhouse gas; (Watch this video to the end!) it holds the most heat and is the most abundant. Cycling water into clouds and rain is the function of the opposing teams of Organic Aerosols vs. Inorganic Aerosols. Organic aerosols cloud seed at moderate temperatures, while Inorganic Aerosols suppress rain and cloud formation until the extremes lead to extreme climate events. While CO2 keeps us busy, uncondensed water vapor is wreaking havoc. Plant-based organic bioaerosols are key in climate recovery and eventual climate management.
Plants, keeping the soil covered with plants is one of the most powerful tools for managing climate. There is hope, and we can do this.
 
Watch the heartbeat of the Amazon Rainforest cycle every day: https://lnkd.in/g4C22T8Z
 
Can Dung Beetles stop Tornadoes by greening prairies? https://lnkd.in/g-Pg24KZ
 
Watch desert dust kick up a wall forming a Haboob to prevent rainfall https://lnkd.in/gX_DY3f4
 
Read how inorganic dust suppresses rainfall.
https://lnkd.in/g9B2-y9H
Check out the latest work of Cindy E Morris https://lnkd.in/gfjcQkcs

Bio:
Co-Founder at Dashboard.Earth

Gayatri Roshan (co-founder, CEO) brings 20 years of experience working in multiple aspects of ecology and environment across non-profit and for-profit sectors. Specializing in film and communications her work has spanned solutions across a diverse range of topics including; the mass extinction, agriculture, architecture, water, and the climate crisis. As a producer and director, she has made three feature films (and numerous short form) working with grassroots and indigenous communities in 40 countries as well as environmental luminaries such as Prince Charles, Paul Hawken & Vandana Shiva. The New York Times called her film ELEMENTAL "A Last Stand for Nature Against Mighty Odds”

She started her career in London where she produced over 50 television and radio commercial campaigns for Sony BMG, Universal Music and Virgin Music. In 2005 she wrote and produced her first documentary feature CALL OF LIFE which explores the mass extinction of species. She went on to write and produce two television half hours: A THOUSAND SUNS (PBS/ABC Australia) on the resistance to the ‘new green revolution’ in Africa and PEACE WANTED ALIVE (Link TV) on Kenya’s grassroots rebuilding after the nations most violent election. She was the producer and executive producer of HARMONY (NBC), a feature-length documentary on deep ecology, inspired by and in collaboration with the Prince of Wales that opened NBC’s Green Week. Gayatri directed her first documentary film ELEMENTAL a verité feature shot over two years on three continents following three people all obsessed with the natural world. The Village Voice called it “Fascinating... Insightful… Stunningly shot” The Film Stage noted the film's "alarming intimacy," saying "Elemental is a rare, fresh look at environmental issues and sustainability that does not shy away from the personal impact the decisions to dedicate one's life to a cause entails.” In the past 20 years Gayatri has filmed in twenty countries across four continents.

Bio:
Dan Kittredge has been an organic farmer for more than 30 years and is the founder and Executive Director of the Bionutrient Food Association (BFA), a non-profit whose mission is to “increase quality in the food supply.” 

Dan grew up on Many Hands Organic Farm in central Massachusetts. After a global career in food and seed activism where he worked with farmers across India, Russia, and Central America, Dan returned to the U.S. and launched the BFA in 2010 to ignite a movement around food quality. 

His resonating message has filled hundreds of workshops and speaking engagements with farmers and eaters alike hungry for answers. To expand upon these concepts is the BFA flagship event, the annual Soil & Nutrition Conference, now in its tenth year that has hosted speakers such as John Kempf, Ray Archuleta, Kathleen DiChiara, David Montgomery, Fred Kirschenmann, Judith Schwartz, Graham Sait, Bernard Pollack, Glen Rein, Dorn Cox, Elaine Ingham, Joel Salatin, Stephan van Vliet, Fred Provenza and many more luminaries in the food and ag sectors.

A born leader in this field, Dan has solidified himself as an expert in the world of “nutrient density” and biological or regenerative agriculture. Through this mission, the Bionutrient Institute was launched, with partner organizations, Our-sci LLC, FarmOS, and Next 7, to demonstrate and share the connections between nutrient density and soil, plant, and human health. 

BFA’s significant growth since 2018 now means three labs in the U.S. and one in Europe are conducting surveys of the food supply, measuring the variation of nutritional compounds found in food, and connecting it to management practices.

In 2021, the Institute unveiled a second-generation prototype of a hand-held consumer spectrometer called the Bionutrient Meter, calibrated by the sampling done at the labs. The meter is designed to test nutritional quality at the point of purchase, bringing transparency to the marketplace and providing growers with the needed tools to increase nutrition in their crops and leverage economic incentives to drive complete system regeneration. 

The most recent lab in Boston is designed to further the mission of our understanding of nutrient density and to engineer an advanced version of the Bionutrient Meter with the data used for calibration all being open source, demonstrating the BFA’s commitment to small landholders and the greater global Commons.

To learn more about this work, visit: Bionutrient.org and BionutrientInstitute.org

I am also certified in Strategic Doing, a disciplined approach to collaboration that enables open networks of interested parties to quickly structure and implement short-term projects that achieve measurable outcomes. Bio: Rob Lewis is a poet, writer and activist working to give voice to the more-than-human world. His writings have appeared in Resilience, Dark Mountain, Atlanta Review, Counterflow and others, as well as the anthologies Singing the Salmon Home and For the Love of Orcas. He’s also author of the poetry/essay collection The Silence of Vanishing Things. Lately, he’s been writing about how the climate isn’t a machine with an engineering fix, but a living system that only can only be healed through restraint and restoration, at https://theclimateaccordingtolife.substack.com/

Name: Robert Bennett

Bio:
Our 501c3 nonprofit, Possible Planet, PossiblePlanet.org, is a dba for the Center for Regenerative Community Solutions, crcsolutions.org, established in 2013.  

We are convening regenerative projects in the bioregion we recently moved to, the Genesee Finger Lakes region of New York State, under the brand Possible Rochester, PossibleRochester.org. We participate with other bioregions organizing as part of the Great Lakes Basin ecosystem and ultimately, a network of Bioregional Learning Centers around the world being created under Joe Brewer and Penny Heipel's Design School for Regenerating Earth, design-school-for-regenerating-earth.mn.co/. Our mission is to re-indigenize ourselves as communities that are grounded "in place," with regenerative cultures and economies. Humans are part of nature, with the role of coherently creating the conditions that allow for land to be regenerated to support biodiversity (the flourishing of life in our bioregion). An essential part of the Design School's process is to establish a self-governing cooperative nonprofit foundation in our bioregion that raises money, collectively, to fund the priority needs of the bioregion represented by the people and projects already involved in regenerative activities. In addition to fundraising, people and projects under the Bioregional Learning Center exchange value through various forms of capital, e.g. intellectual, spiritual, social, material, financial, living (or natural), cultural, and experiential or human, from AppleSeed Permaculture.  

While we are now immersed in regenerating land through a bioregional lens, we have been championing decarbonization over the past decade. 

Since 2013, my husband, Jonathan Cloud, and I have been stewarding an effort to make energy efficiency, renewable energy and resiliency attractive and affordable--even profitable—to developers and commercial building owners through a paradigm-shifting financial tool called C-PACE (Commercial Property Assessed Clean Energy). NJPACE (NJPACE.org) is the brand of our initiative within Possible Planet. C-PACE is enabled through state law that allows long-term, low-cost, fixed-rate, 3rd party private capital to be invested in clean energy and resiliency building measures in a commercial building,.  There are numerous financial and other benefits to stakeholders, including, of course, carbon emissions reductions toward community climate goals. NJ's C-PACE program is finally being launched in early 2025 by the NJ Economic Development Authority (NJEDA). Originating C-PACE projects can generate a revenue stream to fund our nonprofit's work in bioregionalism until nature-based solutions are recognized for the monetary value they create. In our role of spreading the word about C-PACE, it is my intention to have people see the value of C-PACE in the context of a community's efforts to create a regenerative economy as part of bioregional plans to restore nature and biodiversity while reducing carbon emissions. 

Ultimately, I see the possibility of making PACE (Property Assessed Clean Energy) financing a household word when R-PACE, Residential PACE, again becomes a viable bill for legislative consideration, state by state. In the past few years, R-PACE has added consumer protections that make the program harder for unscrupulous contractors to deceive homeowners. Prior, R-PACE became untouchable by legislators when original state programs in CA, FL and MO were lambasted for lax industry procedures to protect homeowners. R-PACE spreads virally, unlike commercial programs; there are 10x as many projects and 10x the investments in R-PACE in just 3 states, as compared with 34 states that have C-PACE programs.

PACE is considered a special assessment, repaid over the long term through property taxes and treated as a government versus a contractual lien with unique and valuable advantages over any other type of asset-based financing. It is experiencing hockey-stick-like growth across the US.
Name: Victoria Zelin Cloud

Bio:
Otherwise known as "Dr. Rain," Professor Moo Young Han is leading the “rainwater revolution.” A professor at Seoul National University, he is recognized for his creative, innovative work on dissolved air flotation and rainwater harvesting, sharing his knowledge with the public and helping underserved communities gain access to clean water.

At the beginning of his academic career, Moo Young performed work on dissolved air flotation, a process to remove particles from water by attaching air bubbles to them, making them dense than water. He became a recognized expert in this area but also had growing interest in rainwater harvesting.

Living in Seoul, he experienced frequent flooding due to substantial rainfalls at times and a high percentage of impervious cover. Moo Young became convinced that the longstanding engineering approach to preventing flooding was fundamentally flawed.

Rather than building sufficiently large piping networks to quickly carry water downstream of cities, he concluded that rain should be captured and used where it falls. As a result, he first worked on "rainwater harvesting," a process where rainwater is captured from rooftops, and collected for beneficial use, such as gardening, toilet flushing or treating drinking water.
Name: Moo Young Han

Bio:
A self-described "Inspiration Strategist," my roles are synergistic: 
* Founder of Unstitution
* Canada Chair Ecocivilization 

I help people and organizations reframe their "why," towards regenerative ways of working and being. Balancing hard science with "messy humanness" and always learning, I draw from transcontextual perspectives and integrative systems thinking to navigate through complexity and uncertainty. The "new stories" embrace our interdependence. My 30+ years of experience is a shared resource. 

I build bridges, forging commons-based ecosystem partnership relationships and patterns, shaping regenerative navigation strategy.

Unstitution is patterned as a collaborative commons, co-catalyzing and supporting "living-learning lab" initiatives and ventures, addressing systemic issues and co-activating regenerative ways of working and living. Co-creating viable pathways from "the space between" sectors, disciplines, networks, cultures, generations - all the "divides." Toward enabling contexts and conditions - alternative forms of governance, work systems, practices and multicapital/capacity economies where value flows in alignment with life-affirming regeneration.  

Addressing and leveraging interconnected local and global systemic challenges and opportunities for the benefit of humanity and a biodiverse living planet.Toward life worth living and work worth doing - a humbling learning journey for us all.

Collectively, we are cultivating places/spaces that nurture a reframed sense of belonging - honouring 'gifts differing' - creativity, diversity, justice and our rooted Indigeneity. A dance of emergence AND strategy.

Our suite of Unstitution articles are published on Medium.They reflect a small sample of the ways we are adapting and contributing among ever-expanding commons-based communities and initiatives inspired by denizens — anywhere in the world — living into the principles and spirit that govern our collaborative work. Each article is a fractal-like glimpse into the 'unstitutional' ethos.
https://bit.ly/Unstitution21

Bio:
My focus is learning from indigenous wisdoms, and regenerative agricultural practices to support communities around the world. I specialize in connecting universities with global projects to drive industry standards to progress integration of climate initiatives through agricultural and closed-loop systems. 

On-site I perform full systems analysis when involved in communities focusing on maximizing SDG impacts and integrating climate and carbon smart integrations. These practices include soil and biomass nutrient testing and contamination remediation through phyto- and bio- remediation strategies to clean soils and water systems.

I utilize the indigenous mentality of generational impacts through life cycle analysis to ensure we maximize impacts with minimal impact. We're then able to build systems to produce climate smart commodities that support the community and the local ecosystems.
Name: Jeremy Hale

Bio:
Samantha Power is a Co-Founder and the Director of the BioFi Project and the Founder and Principal Consultant of Finance for Gaia. She is a Regenerative Economist, Futurist, and Bioregionalist based in Oakland, CA on the ancestral land of the Ohlone people. She is a co-author of the book, 'Bioregional Financing Facilities: Reimagining Finance to Regenerate Our Planet.' Samantha believes we need to build a new layer in the global financial architecture to halt the sixth mass extinction and she is dedicating her life to doing just that. 

For 15 years now, Samantha has been asking “How do we change where money is flowing so that it supports, rather than destroys, life?” This question has taken her to many different geographies, communities, and institutions — from rapidly disappearing rainforests across Southeast Asia, women’s community lending circles in Myanmar, the US Treasury Department, the UN, the World Bank, as well as the impact investing community.

Ultimately, it landed her amidst the redwoods in the San Francisco Bay Area, where Samantha took stock of what she had learned trying to change financial flows from the top down. She began deepening her listening to the people she saw doing the most urgent work in the world right now: regenerating the Earth’s lands and waters. She learned that the Indigenous land stewards, regenerative farmers, community builders, and regenerative systems designers from around the world were not able to access the financial resources needed to support their critical work, and imagined a set of new bioregional-scale financial institutions and organizing infrastructure, strategically coordinated to regenerate ecosystems and economic systems at scale. 

Samantha channeled what she learned into a new book: 'Bioregional Financing Facilities: Reimagining Finance to Regenerate Our Planet.' The book makes the case for, and explains how to build institutions to shift capital to place-based regenerators to achieve global climate and nature-related goals, while enabling the transition to regenerative economies. To turn this vision into a global movement, Samantha co-founded the BioFi Project — a collective of experts supporting bioregions around the world to design, build, and implement BFFs inspired by the templates laid out in the book.
Name: Samantha Power

Bio: Alex Carlin promotes ocean plankton restoration initiatives in West Africa through the Africa Climate Band, a reggae ensemble spreading climate solutions across Ghana, Togo, Benin, and Ivory Coast. His work focuses on plankton ecosystems—where most of Earth's photosynthesis occurs—as a strategy for addressing ocean temperature and acidification. Alex created the anthem "Africa Will Be the Leader" to reframe climate narratives: "Africa will be the leader in the climate solution today." The song positions African nations as climate leaders rather than victims, challenging decades of Western-led climate approaches. Alex combines music, public engagement (concerts and press conferences), and marine ecosystem restoration.

Bio:
About
Tom Biebighauser has restored over 2,900 wetlands and streams across Canada, in 26-States, Mexico, New Zealand, Puerto Rico, and Taiwan since 1979. He has developed highly effective and low-cost techniques for building wetlands and streams for endangered and threatened species of plants and animals. Tom retired from the US Forest Service in 2013, after working 34-years as a Wildlife Biologist where he initiated wetland and stream restoration programs across the United States. Having built over 1,400-dams, he has since decommissioned over 300-dams. Tom instructs a Graduate-level class on Wetland Design at the University of Louisville Speed School of Engineering, along with classes for the University of Alberta and the British Columbia Institute Technology. He has written 4-books about wetland restoration and has received 45-awards for his outstanding contributions.

Bio:
My name is Annika Lundkvist and I am currently based in Warsaw where I am a PhD student at the Institute for Geography and Spatial Organization (Polish Academy of Sciences) where my research focuses on issues of walkability and biophilic urbanism as crucial for developing sustainable cities. I value working with a highly interdisciplinary approach.

I am the founder of pedestrianspace.org, a platform devoted to walkability, sustainable mobility and urbanism issues. Pedestrian Space is also registered as an NGO/foundation in Poland. 

I am also co-founder of Urban Transit Lab, a participatory media, research and communication initiative designed to help accelerate the sustainable mobility shift and amplify the stories and communication of city inhabitants regarding mobility. We are launching our first two partnered programs this month. 

Lastly, I founded and co-facilitate the Global Walkability Correspondents Network, an international network of primarily professionals but also many advocates whose work in some way connects to the central role of sustainable mobility for healthy communities. 

I am also working on the foundation for some new projects about how critical it is to center nature in cities and am also interested in doing more work related to resilience, keeping in mind the climate migration that is likely to escalate in coming years.
Name: Annika Lundkvist

Experienced at branding, marketing, and sales, I co-founded publications and innovated products while working collaboratively to develop new markets, such as Computer User magazine which was our country’s first regional computer publication, publishing monthly for 24 years. Bio:
At Munansi Green Initiative, we are deeply committed to restoring the climate by regenerating the biosphere through two flagship projects: Munansi Hives and our Fruit & Food Forests initiative.
Munansi Hives Project
We empower smallholder farmers and youth with sustainable beekeeping skills by providing Kenyan Top Bar (KTB) hives and training on pollinator protection and hive management. Bees are crucial to biodiversity and ecosystem regeneration. Our project currently supports over 150 farmers and has introduced wild bee-saving methods, which not only enhance crop yields through pollination but also protect native pollinator species vital to healthy ecosystems.
 Fruit & Food Forests
In collaboration with schools and communities, we’ve established a 2-acre food and fruit forest model serving over 400 students and their families. These forests are planted with indigenous fruit trees, medicinal plants, and nutrient-rich vegetables that restore soil health, sequester carbon, and promote food security. We also use this space as a living classroom for youth to learn about agroecology, permaculture, and climate action.
Why We Should Be on the Map
Our work combines climate restoration, community resilience, and nature-based solutions. We integrate traditional knowledge with modern environmental practices, create green jobs for youth and women, and promote circular resource use at the grassroots level. We’re not just planting trees; we’re cultivating ecosystems of hope and resilience. We’d be honored to be on your map as a living example of biosphere regeneration and climate justice in action.
Name: Munansi Green Initiaitive

Bio: Data Scientist at Eneco. I love solving problems and making sense out of data, and I’m looking forward to combining this with my other passion, nature-based solutions and climate action. I can bring lots of motivation, initiative, creativity and eagerness to learn new things.

Since 2007, she has organized numerous local sustainability events and has given many presentations and lectures regarding the impacts of fossil fuel depletion on industrial society. Bio:
Founder and Director, Inga Foundation. Mike Hands has been working to halt the destruction of the rainforest for over 20 years. An experienced tropical ecologist and scientific researcher, Mike divides his time between his farm in Cornwall, UK, and the Inga Foundations chief project, the Land for Life Project in Honduras.

Mike developed the revolutionary agricultural system of Inga Alley Cropping through years of scientific research into slash and burn farming and founded the Inga Foundation to help popularise this method. He is now working closely with families to implement this sustainable method in place of slash and burn practices.

For Honduran campensinos (subsistence farmers), changing farming methods is a huge and difficult decision. Given that their lives depend on the food they produce, these farmers have good reason to be conservative in their decision-making. Mike, a Cornish farmer as well as an ecologist, has always emphasised the importance of establishing trust, understanding and compassion when working together with the local people.

"Mike Hands – no. 44 in top 100 contributors to saving the planet” – THE GUARDIAN
Name: Mike Hands

Bio:
Sean Petterson leads Supersede, transforming recycled plastics into high-performance, waterproof sheathing as a sustainable plywood alternative for industrial, specialty vehicle, and construction markets.

A seasoned entrepreneur, Sean founded StrongArm Technologies, pioneering industrial safety wearables and AI-driven injury prevention. StrongArm secured patents, raised venture capital, and was recognized by Fast Company and TIME before its 2023 acquisition.

Sean advises industrial firms and manufacturing startups. At Supersede, he applies his expertise in manufacturing, IP strategy, and supply chain scaling to drive sustainable, high-performance materials innovation.
Name: Sean Petterson

Bio: We cofounded Permaculture Living Lands Trust to combine the strengths of the conservation and permaculture movements in service of a new land commons for agroforestry and human ecological design to flourish. We hold land in trust for community and ecological benefit, including community food forests, tree crop nurseries and ecological learning centers. Our primary focus at this time is the Eastern Temperate Forest of North America, with the goal of serving community needs internationally.
Name: David Harper

Bio: Jacob Denlinger is a high school junior from Phoenix, Arizona, who interns with the EcoRestoration Alliance while managing responsibilities that would challenge most adults. An Eagle Scout from Brophy College Preparatory, Jacob has worked on Arizona political campaigns focusing on environmental policy, particularly EPA, Department of Transportation, and Department of Energy regulations around permaculture and sustainable agriculture. Despite describing politics as "slow," he engaged with the Chevron deference case and primary campaigns. At ERA, Jacob contributes to website development and organizational infrastructure, bringing technical skills and policy awareness while balancing his junior year coursework.
Name: Jacob Denlinger
